Argument: Statement1: After the second world war, the charter of the newly formed united nations established an eleven-member security council and charged it with taking collective action in response to threats to world peace. Statement2: The charter further provided that the five nations that were then the major powers would permanently have sole authority to cast vetoes. Statement3: The reason given for this arrangement was that the burden of maintaining world peace would rest on the world's major powers, and no nation should be required to assume the burden of enforcing a decision it found repugnant.
Premise1: No nation that was not among the major powers at the end of the second world war would become a major power
Premise2: Decisions reached by a majority of nations in response to threats to world peace would be biased in favor of one or more major powers

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: After the second world war, the charter of the newly formed united nations established an eleven-member security council and charged it with taking collective action in response to threats to world peace. Statement2: The charter further provided that the five nations that were then the major powers would permanently have sole authority to cast vetoes. Statement3: The reason given for this arrangement was that the burden of maintaining world peace would rest on the five major powers, and and the decision made by security council won't be biased in favor of any major powers.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Decisions reached by a majority of nations in response to threats to world peace would be biased in favor of one or more major powers
input_info.O: Premise1: No nation that was not among the major powers at the end of the second world war would become a major power
input_info.P: Statement1: After the second world war, the charter of the newly formed united nations established an eleven-member security council and charged it with taking collective action in response to threats to world peace. Statement2: The charter further provided that the five nations that were then the major powers would permanently have sole authority to cast vetoes. Statement3: The reason given for this arrangement was that the burden of maintaining world peace would rest on the world's major powers, and no nation should be required to assume the burden of enforcing a decision it found repugnant.

Argument: Statement1: The press reports on political campaigns these days as if they were chess games. Statement2: One candidate's campaign advisor makes a move ; the other candidate's advisor makes a countermove. Statement3: The press then reports on the campaign advisors and not on the candidates. Statement4: The losers in this chess game are the voters. Statement5: They are deprived of the information they need to make informed decisions because the press is ignoring substantive policy issues and reporting only on the process of the campaign. Statement6: It is clear that the campaign advisors should stay out of the limelight and let the press report on the most revealing positions on substantive issues the candidates have taken.
Premise1: The candidates in the election are taking positions on substantive policy issues.
Premise2: There is no difference between reporting on the political process and reporting on substantive issues.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: The press reports on political campaigns these days as if they were chess games. Statement2: One candidate's campaign advisor makes a move ; the other candidate's advisor makes a countermove. Statement3: The press then reports on the campaign advisors and not on the candidates. Statement4: . Statement5: And the press is reporting only on the process of the campaign. Statement6: It is clear that the press reports on the most revealing positions on substantive issues the candidates have taken.

input_info.Om: Premise2: There is no difference between reporting on the political process and reporting on substantive issues.
input_info.O: Premise1: The candidates in the election are taking positions on substantive policy issues.

Statement4: Therefore, this type of directed learning is likely to improve a child's preschool education.

Statement4: This, therefore, must have not been the earliest bird --.

Argument: Statement1: Critic : works of literature often present protagonists who scorn allegiance to their society and who advocate detachment rather than civic-mindedness. However, modern literature is distinguished from the literature of earlier eras in part because it more frequently treats such protagonists sympathetically. Statement2: Sympathetic treatment of such characters suggests to readers that one should be unconcerned about contributing to societal good. Statement3: Thus, modern literature can damage individuals who appropriate this attitude, as well as damage society at large.
Premise1: It is to the advantage of some individuals that they be concerned with contributing to societal good.
Premise2: Some individuals must believe that their society is better than most before they can become concerned with benefiting it.

output: Statement1: Critic : works of literature often present protagonists who scorn allegiance to their society and who advocate detachment rather than civic-mindedness. However, modern literature is distinguished from the literature of earlier eras in part because it more frequently treats such protagonists sympathetically. Statement3: Sympathetic treatment of such characters suggests to readers that one should not believe that their society is better than most. Statement4: Thus, modern literature can damage individuals who appropriate this attitude, as well as damage society at large.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Some individuals must believe that their society is better than most before they can become concerned with benefiting it.
input_info.O: Premise1: It is to the advantage of some individuals that they be concerned with contributing to societal good.

Argument: Statement1: The profitability of a business is reduced by anything that undermines employee morale. Argument: Statement1: A recent epidemiological study found that businesspeople who travel internationally on business are much more likely to suffer from chronic insomnia than are businesspeople who do not travel on business. International travelers experience the stresses of dramatic changes in climate, frequent disruption of daily routines, and immersion in cultures other than their own, stresses not commonly felt by those who do not travel. Statement2: Thus, it is likely that these stresses cause the insomnia.
Premise1: Businesspeople who already suffer from chronic insomnia are no more likely than businesspeople who do not to accept assignments from their employers that require international travel.
Premise2: Experiencing dramatic changes in climate and disruption of daily routines through international travel can be beneficial to some people who suffer from chronic insomnia.

Please write the modified argument below:

International travelers experience the stresses of dramatic changes in climate, frequent disruption of daily routines, and immersion in cultures other than their own, stresses not commonly felt by those who do not travel. Statement3: Thus, it is likely that these stresses cure the insomnia.

Argument: Statement1: The everyday behavior of whales is particularly difficult to study because introducing novel stimuli, such as divers or submarines, into the whales'environment causes whales to behave in unusual ways. Statement3: They argue that since whales are accustomed to there being sea lions nearby, using the sea lions to film the whales would allow biologists to study the everyday behavior of the whales.

Premise2: Sea lions carrying video cameras will be able to film whales at a much closer range than divers can.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Sea lions carrying video cameras will be able to film whales at a much closer range than divers can.

Argument: Statement1: Efforts to get the public to exercise regularly, which have emphasized the positive health effects of exercise rather than the dangers of a sedentary lifestyle, have met with little success. Statement2: In contrast, efforts to curb cigarette smoking, which have emphasized the dangers of smoking rather than the positive health effects of quitting, have been highly successful. Statement3: Thus, efforts to get the public to exercise regularly would be more successful if they emphasized the dangers of a sedentary lifestyle rather than the positive health effects of exercise.

Premise2: The majority of people who successfully quit smoking cite health concerns as the primary motivation for their success.

Statement2: In contrast, efforts to curb cigarette smoking, which have emphasized the fact that it will increase the probability of lung cancer, have been highly successful. Statement3: Thus, efforts to get the public to exercise regularly would be more successful if they emphasized the fact that sedentary lifestyle will also increase the probability of people getting some fatal diseases.

input_info.Om: Premise2: The majority of people who successfully quit smoking cite health concerns as the primary motivation for their success.

Argument: Statement1: In a study conducted in pennsylvania, servers in various restaurants wrote" thank you" on randomly selected bills before presenting the bills to their customers. Premise2: The "thank you" messages would have the same impact on regular patrons of a restaurant as they would on occasional patrons of the same restaurant.

Statement3: Therefore, if servers in pennsylvania regularly wrote" thank you" on restaurant bills, their average income from tips of regular patrons would be significantly higher than it otherwise would have been.

Argument: Statement1: Manufacturers of writing paper need to add mineral" filler" to paper pulp if the paper made from the pulp is to look white. To make writing paper that looks white from recycled paper requires more filler than is required to make such paper from other sources. Statement2: Without such filler, paper products look grayish. Statement3: Therefore, barring the more efficient use of fillers in paper manufacturing or the development of paper-whitening technologies that do not require mineral fillers, if writing paper made from recycled paper comes to replace other types of writing paper, paper manufacturers will have to use more filler than they now use.
Premise1: Grayish writing paper will not be a universally acceptable alternative to white writing paper.
Premise2: Certain kinds of paper cannot be manufactured from recycled paper.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Manufacturers of writing paper need to add mineral" filler" to paper pulp if the paper made from the pulp is to look white. Fillers are expensive. To make writing paper that looks white from recycled paper requires less filler than is required to make such paper from other sources. Statement2: And paper products from recycled paper look grayish. This paper is of better quality and costs less. Statement4: Therefore, barring the more efficient use of fillers in paper manufacturing or the development of paper-whitening technologies that do not require mineral fillers, in order to save costs writing paper that look grayish and made from recycled paper comes to replace other types of writing paper ,except for a few specific paper types,even though they are expensive to make.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Certain kinds of paper cannot be manufactured from recycled paper.
input_info.O: Premise1: Grayish writing paper will not be a universally acceptable alternative to white writing paper.

Argument: Statement1: Computer manufacturers have sought to make computer chips ever smaller, since decreasing the size of a computer's central processing unit ( cpu ) chip -- without making that cpu chip any less sophisticated -- will proportionally increase the speed of the cpu chip and the computer containing it. Statement2: But since cpu chips can not be made significantly smaller without decreasing their sophistication, computers can not currently be made significantly faster.
Premise1: Computers cannot currently be made faster unless their cpu chips are made smaller.
Premise2: If both the size and the sophistication of a cpu chip are decreased, the speed of that chip will decrease.

Statement2: But since cpu chips only can be made significantly smaller by decreasing their sophistication, computers can not currently be made significantlyfaster by decreasing the size of the cpu ship.

input_info.Om: Premise2: If both the size and the sophistication of a cpu chip are decreased, the speed of that chip will decrease.
input_info.O: Premise1: Computers cannot currently be made faster unless their cpu chips are made smaller.
input_info.P: Statement1: Computer manufacturers have sought to make computer chips ever smaller, since decreasing the size of a computer's central processing unit ( cpu ) chip -- without making that cpu chip any less sophisticated -- will proportionally increase the speed of the cpu chip and the computer containing it. Statement2: But since cpu chips can not be made significantly smaller without decreasing their sophistication, computers can not currently be made significantly faster.

Argument: Statement1: Native speakers perceive sentences of their own language as sequences of separate words. Statement4: Thus the number of early byzantine documents sealed in such a fashion must have been many times the number of remaining lead seals.

Argument: Statement1: A recent study suggests that alzheimer's disease, which attacks the human brain, may be caused by a virus. Statement2: In the study, blood from 11 volunteers, each of whom had the disease, was injected into rats. Statement3: The rats eventually exhibited symptoms of another degenerative neurological disorder, creutzfeldt-jakob disease, which is caused by a virus. Statement4: This led the scientist who conducted the study to conclude that alzheimer's disease might be caused by a virus.
Premise1: The symptoms known, respectively, as creutzfeldt-jakob disease and alzheimer's disease are different manifestations of the same disease.
Premise2: Creutzfeldt-jakob disease affects only motor nerves in rats' limbs, not their brains.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: A recent study suggests that alzheimer's disease, which attacks the human brain, may be caused by a virus. Statement2: In the study, blood from 11 volunteers, each of whom had the disease, was injected into rats. Statement3: The rats eventually exhibited symptoms of another degenerative neurological disorder, creutzfeldt-jakob disease, which is caused by virus mutation. Statement4: The source of virus variation can only be another virus. Meanwhile, the mutated virus is more likely to attack from the limbs. This led the scientist who conducted the study to conclude that alzheimer's disease might be caused by a virus.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following statements, if true, would most strengthen the scientist's hypothesis that alzheimer's disease is caused by a virus?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Creutzfeldt-jakob disease affects only motor nerves in rats' limbs, not their brains.
input_info.O: Premise1: The symptoms known, respectively, as creutzfeldt-jakob disease and alzheimer's disease are different manifestations of the same disease.
input_info.P: Statement1: A recent study suggests that alzheimer's disease, which attacks the human brain, may be caused by a virus. Statement2: In the study, blood from 11 volunteers, each of whom had the disease, was injected into rats. Statement3: The rats eventually exhibited symptoms of another degenerative neurological disorder, creutzfeldt-jakob disease, which is caused by a virus. Statement4: This led the scientist who conducted the study to conclude that alzheimer's disease might be caused by a virus.

Argument: Statement1: Spiders of many species change color to match the pigmentation of the flowers they sit on. Statement2: The insects preyed on by those spiders, unlike human beings, possess color discrimination so acute that they can readily see the spiders despite the seeming camouflage. Statement3: Clearly, then, it must be in evading their own predators that the spiders'color changes are useful to them.
Premise1: The color discrimination of certain birds that feed on color-changing spiders is no more acute than that of human beings.
Premise2: Color-changing spiders possess color discrimination that is more acute than that of spiders that lack the ability to change color.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Spiders of many species change color to match the pigmentation of the flowers they sit on. Statement2: The insects preyed on by those spiders, unlike human beings, possess color discrimination and sometimes they can see the spiders despite the seeming camouflage. And the insects can always see the spiders without the ability to change color. Statement3: So, those spiders will try their best to hide themselves in the petals of similar colors to prevent themselves from being found.

input_info.Q: Which of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Color-changing spiders possess color discrimination that is more acute than that of spiders that lack the ability to change color.
input_info.O: Premise1: The color discrimination of certain birds that feed on color-changing spiders is no more acute than that of human beings.
input_info.P: Statement1: Spiders of many species change color to match the pigmentation of the flowers they sit on. Statement2: The insects preyed on by those spiders, unlike human beings, possess color discrimination so acute that they can readily see the spiders despite the seeming camouflage. Statement3: Clearly, then, it must be in evading their own predators that the spiders'color changes are useful to them.

Argument: Statement1: A survey has shown that public perceptions of comparative risks differ radically from the assessments of risk-management experts. Statement2: For example, living near a nuclear power plant was judged a much greater risk by the survey respondents than it was by the experts. On the other hand, exposure to x-rays was judged a significantly lower risk by the survey respondents than it was by the experts. Statement3: Psychologists have found that people tend to be more worried about risks they consider involuntary than about risks they consider voluntary. Statement4: Thus the survey results were probably caused by the respondents'tendency to consider involuntary risks to be greater than they actually are.
Premise1: Not all of the survey respondents considered living near a nuclear power plant to be a voluntary risk.
Premise2: The survey's respondents did not include people living near nuclear power plants.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: A survey has shown that public perceptions of comparative risks differ radically from the assessments of risk-management experts. Statement2: For example, living near a nuclear power plant was judged a much greater risk by the survey respondents than it was by the experts. On the other hand, exposure to x-rays was judged a significantly lower risk by the survey respondents than it was by the experts. Statement4: Psychologists have found that people tend to be more worried about risks they are not experienced than about risks they have already experienced. Statement5: Thus the survey results were probably caused by the respondents'tendency to consider not experienced risks to be greater than they actually are.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: The survey's respondents did not include people living near nuclear power plants.
input_info.O: Premise1: Not all of the survey respondents considered living near a nuclear power plant to be a voluntary risk.

On the other hand, exposure to x-rays was judged a significantly lower risk by the survey respondents than it was by the experts. Statement3: Psychologists have found that people tend to be more worried about risks they consider involuntary than about risks they consider voluntary. Statement4: Thus the survey results were probably caused by the respondents'tendency to consider involuntary risks to be greater than they actually are.

Argument: Statement1: One of the most important events for modern astronomy was the series of collisions, during a single week in 1994, of more than a dozen large objects with jupiter. Statement2: The collision of these objects, which once formed most of the comet shoemaker-levy 9, resulted in formations that showed no signs of water. Statement3: There was thus no water involved in the collisions, so we know that none of the comet's fragments penetrated to jupiter's lower atmosphere and that the comet was composed of rock rather than ice.
Premise1: If jupiter's lower atmosphere had been penetrated by the comet's fragments, the resulting formations would show signs of water.
Premise2: Comets tend to be composed largely of ice while asteroids are composed mainly of rock.

Statement3: There was thus water involved in the collisions, so we know that the comet's fragments has penetrated to jupiter's lower atmosphere and that the comet was composed of ice rather than rock.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Comets tend to be composed largely of ice while asteroids are composed mainly of rock.
input_info.O: Premise1: If jupiter's lower atmosphere had been penetrated by the comet's fragments, the resulting formations would show signs of water.

input_info.Om: Premise2: As dolphins age, they accumulate toxins from the environment more slowly than when they were young.
input_info.O: Premise1: The survival rate of firstborn dolphin calves in the area along florida's gulf coast is highest for those whose mothers were killed before they were weaned.
input_info.P: Statement1: In polluted environments, dolphins gradually accumulated toxins in their body fat, and the larger the dolphin the more accumulated toxin it can tolerate. Nearly 80 percent of the toxins a female dolphin has accumulated pass into the fat-rich milk her nursing calf ingests. Statement2: Therefore, the unusually high mortality rate among dolphin calves in the industrially contaminated waters along florida's gulf coast is probably the result of their being poisoned by their mother's milk.

Argument: Statement1: Advertisers are often criticized for their unscrupulous manipulation of people's tastes and wants. Statement2: There is evidence, however, that some advertisers are motivated by moral as well as financial considerations. Statement3: A particular publication decided to change its image from being a family newspaper to concentrating on sex and violence, thus appealing to a different readership. Statement4: Some advertisers withdrew their advertisements from the publication, and this must have been because they morally disapproved of publishing salacious material.
Premise1: The advertisers expected their product sales to increase if they stayed with the changed publication, but to decrease if they withdrew.
Premise2: People who generally read family newspapers are not likely to buy newspapers that concentrate on sex and violence.

Please write the modified argument below:

Statement2: There is evidence that some advertisers are motivated only by financial considerations. Statement3: A particular publication decided to change its image from being a family newspaper to concentrating on sex and violence, thus appealing to a different readership. Statement4: Some advertisers withdrew their advertisements from the publication, and this couldn't have been because they morally disapproved of publishing salacious material. It's because the current audience of newspapers does not fit their positioning as the buyer of the product.

input_info.Om: Premise2: People who generally read family newspapers are not likely to buy newspapers that concentrate on sex and violence.
input_info.O: Premise1: The advertisers expected their product sales to increase if they stayed with the changed publication, but to decrease if they withdrew.

Argument: Statement1: It is said that people should accept themselves as they are instead of being dissatisfied with their own abilities. Argument: Statement1: In response to mounting public concern, an airplane manufacturer implemented a program with the well-publicized goal of reducing by half the total yearly amount of hazardous waste generated by its passenger-jet division. Premise2: The average number of weekly hours per production worker in the passenger-jet division was not significantly greater last year than it was in 1994.

Statement2: When the program began in 1994, in the average number of weekly hours, the division's hazardous waste output was 90 pounds per production worker ; last year it was 40 pounds per production worker. Statement3: Clearly, therefore, charges that the manufacturer's program has not met its goal are false.

Argument: Statement1: Exposure to certain chemicals commonly used in elementary schools as cleaners or pesticides causes allergic reactions in some children. Statement2: Elementary school nurses in renston report that the proportion of schoolchildren sent to them for treatment of allergic reactions to those chemicals has increased significantly over the past ten years. Statement3: Therefore, either renston's schoolchildren have been exposed to greater quantities of the chemicals, or they are more sensitive to them than schoolchildren were ten years ago.

Premise2: Children who are allergic to the chemicals are no more likely than other children to have allergies to other substances.

input_info.O: Premise1: Children who have allergic reactions to the chemicals are not more likely to be sent to a school nurse now than they were ten years ago.

Argument: Statement1: Shy adolescents often devote themselves totally to a hobby to help distract them from the loneliness brought on by their shyness. Statement2: Sometimes they are able to become friends with others who share their hobby. Statement3: But if they lose interest in that hobby, their loneliness may be exacerbated. Statement4: So developing an all-consuming hobby is not a successful strategy for overcoming adolescent loneliness.
Premise1: No successful strategy for overcoming adolescent loneliness ever intensifies that loneliness.
Premise2: Shy adolescents devote themselves to hobbies mainly because they want to make friends.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Shy adolescents often devote themselves totally to a hobby to help distract them from the loneliness brought on by their shyness. Statement2: Always they are able to become friends with others who share their hobby .they may lose interest in the hobby after making friends. Statement3: Even though they lose interest in that hobby, their loneliness won't be exacerbated. Statement4: So developing an all-consuming hobby is a successful strategy for overcoming adolescent loneliness.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following assumptions does the argument depend on?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Shy adolescents devote themselves to hobbies mainly because they want to make friends.
input_info.O: Premise1: No successful strategy for overcoming adolescent loneliness ever intensifies that loneliness.

Argument: Statement1: The familiar slogan" survival of the fittest" is popularly used to express the claim, often mistakenly attributed to evolutionary biologists, that the fittest are most likely to survive. However, biologists use the term" fittest" to mean" most likely to survive, " so the slogan is merely claiming that the most likely to survive are the most likely to survive. Statement2: While this claim is clearly true, it is a tautology and so is neither informative nor of scientific interest.
Premise1: The truth of a purported scientific claim is not sufficient for it to be of scientific interest.
Premise2: Only claims that are true are of scientific interest.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: The familiar slogan" survival of the fittest" is popularly used to express the claim, often mistakenly attributed to evolutionary biologists, that the fittest are most likely to survive. However, biologists use the term" fittest" to mean" most likely to survive, " so the slogan is merely claiming that the most likely to survive are the most likely to survive. Statement3: This claim is clearly not true, so it is not of scientific interest.

input_info.Q: The argument above depends on assuming which one of the following?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Only claims that are true are of scientific interest.
input_info.O: Premise1: The truth of a purported scientific claim is not sufficient for it to be of scientific interest.

Argument: Statement1: Market research traditionally entails surveying consumers about why they buy and use particular products and brands. Statement2: Observational research -- actually watching consumers shopping and interacting with products -- is now increasingly used by market researchers to supplement surveys. Statement3: Market researchers claim that observational research yields information about consumer behavior that surveys alone can not provide.
Premise1: Even consumers who are unable to explain their preference for or rejection of particular brands reveal which brands they are considering by picking up and putting down products while they are shopping.
Premise2: Consumers are more likely to respond to oral surveys than they are to respond to written questionnaires.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Market research traditionally entails surveying consumers with written questionnaires about why they buy and use particular products and brands. Statement2: Observational research -- actually watching consumers shopping and interacting with products -- is now increasingly used by market researchers to supplement surveys. Statement3: Market researchers claim that observational research yields information form oral surveys about consumer behavior that written questionnaires alone can not provide.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following, if true, provides the strongest support for the market researchers' claim?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Consumers are more likely to respond to oral surveys than they are to respond to written questionnaires.
input_info.O: Premise1: Even consumers who are unable to explain their preference for or rejection of particular brands reveal which brands they are considering by picking up and putting down products while they are shopping.
input_info.P: Statement1: Market research traditionally entails surveying consumers about why they buy and use particular products and brands. Statement2: Observational research -- actually watching consumers shopping and interacting with products -- is now increasingly used by market researchers to supplement surveys. Statement3: Market researchers claim that observational research yields information about consumer behavior that surveys alone can not provide.

Argument: Statement1: Teresa : if their goal is to maximize profits, film studios should concentrate on producing bigbudget films rather than small-budget ones. Statement2: For, unlike big-budget films, small-budget films never attract mass audiences. Statement3: While small-budget films are less expensive to produce and, hence, involve less risk of unprofitability than big-budget films, low production costs do not guarantee the highest possible profits.

Argument: Statement1: Fossil-fuel producers say that it would be prohibitively expensive to reduce levels of carbon dioxide emitted by the use of fossil fuels enough to halt global warming. This claim is probably false. Statement2: Several years ago, the chemical industry said that finding an economical alternative to the chlorofluorocarbons ( cfcs ) destroying the ozone layer would be impossible. Yet once the industry was forced, by international agreements, to find substitutes for cfcs, it managed to phase them out completely well before the mandated deadline, in many cases at a profit.

Argument: Statement1: Amphibian populations are declining in numbers worldwide. Not coincidentally, the earth's ozone layer has been continuously depleted throughout the last 50 years. Statement2: Atmospheric ozone blocks uv-b, a type of ultraviolet radiation that is continuously produced by the sun, and which can damage genes. Statement3: Because amphibians lack hair, hide, or feathers to shield them, they are particularly vulnerable to uv-b radiation. In addition, their gelatinous eggs lack the protection of leathery or hard shells. Statement4: Thus, the primary cause of the declining amphibian population is the depletion of the ozone layer.
Premise1: Of the various types of radiation blocked by atmospheric ozone, uv-b is the only type that can damage genes.
Premise2: Amphibian populations have declined continuously for the last 50 years.

Argument: Statement1: When permits for the discharge of chemicals into a waterway are issued, they are issued in terms of the number of pounds of each chemical that can be discharged into the waterway per day. These figures, calculated separately for each chemical for which a permit is issued, are based on an estimate of the effect of the dilution of the chemical by the amount of water flowing through the waterway. Statement2: The waterway is therefore protected against being adversely affected by chemicals discharged under the permits.
Premise1: Relatively harmless chemicals do not interact with each other in the water to form harmful compounds
Premise2: There are no chemicals for which discharge into waterways is entirely prohibited

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: When permits for the discharge of chemicals into a waterway are issued, they are issued in terms of the number of pounds of each chemical that can be discharged into the waterway per day. These figures, calculated separately for each chemical for which a permit is issued, are based on an estimate of the effect of the dilution of the chemical by the amount of water flowing through the waterway. Statement3: Therefore, any chemicals can be discharged under their permits.

input_info.Q: The argument depends on the assumption that
input_info.Om: Premise2: There are no chemicals for which discharge into waterways is entirely prohibited
input_info.O: Premise1: Relatively harmless chemicals do not interact with each other in the water to form harmful compounds
input_info.P: Statement1: When permits for the discharge of chemicals into a waterway are issued, they are issued in terms of the number of pounds of each chemical that can be discharged into the waterway per day. These figures, calculated separately for each chemical for which a permit is issued, are based on an estimate of the effect of the dilution of the chemical by the amount of water flowing through the waterway. Statement2: The waterway is therefore protected against being adversely affected by chemicals discharged under the permits.

Argument: Statement1: In an experiment, researchers played a series of musical intervals -- two-note sequences -- to a large, diverse group of six-month-old babies. They found that the babies paid significantly more attention when the intervals were perfect octaves, fifths, or fourths than otherwise. These intervals are prevalent in the musical systems of most cultures around the world. Statement2: Thus, humans probably have a biological predisposition to pay more attention to those intervals than to others.
Premise1: None of the babies in the experiment had previous exposure to music from any culture.
Premise2: Several similar experiments using older children and adults found that these subjects, too, had a general tendency to pay more attention to octaves, fifths, and fourths than to other musical intervals.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: In an experiment, researchers played a series of musical intervals -- two-note sequences -- to a large, diverse group of six-month-old babies. They found that the babies paid significantly more attention when the intervals were perfect octaves, fifths, or fourths than otherwise. These intervals are prevalent in the musical systems of most cultures around the world. Statement4: Thus, humans regardless of age, probably have a biological predisposition to pay more attention to those intervals than to others.

input_info.O: Premise1: None of the babies in the experiment had previous exposure to music from any culture.

Argument: Statement1: Many industrialized nations are trying to reduce atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide, a gas released by the burning of fossil fuels. Statement2: One proposal is to replace conventional cement, which is made with calcium carbonate, by a new" eco-cement. " Statement3: This new cement, made with magnesium carbonate, absorbs large amount of carbon dioxide when exposed to the atmosphere. Statement4: Therefore, using eco-cement for new concrete building projects will significantly help reduce atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide.
Premise1: The manufacture of eco-cement uses considerably less fossil fuel per unit of cement than the manufacture of conventional cement does.
Premise2: Eco-cement is strengthened when absorbed carbon dioxide reacts with the cement.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Many industrialized nations are trying to reduce atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide, a gas released by the burning of fossil fuels. Statement2: One proposal is to replace conventional cement, which is made with calcium carbonate, by a new" eco-cement. " Statement3: This new cement, made with magnesium carbonate, absorbs large amount of carbon dioxide when exposed to the atmosphere. Argument: Statement1: Juries in criminal trials do not base verdicts on uncorroborated testimony given by any one witness. Rightly so, because it is usually prudent to be highly skeptical of unsubstantiated claims made by any one person. Statement2: But then, to be consistent, juries should end an all-too-common practice : convicting defendants on the basis of an uncorroborated full confession.
Premise1: Highly suggestible people who are accused of wrongdoing sometimes become so unsure of their own recollection of the past that they can come to accept the accusations made against them.
Premise2: Defendants sometimes make full confessions when they did in fact do what they are accused of doing and have come to believe that the prosecutor has compelling proof of this.

Argument: Statement1: How the pigment known as han purple was synthesized by the ancient chinese of the qin and han dynasties has puzzled scientists. Statement2: The chinese chemists employed the same chemical ingredients used for han purple in the production of a common type of white glass during that period. Statement3: Both were produced in processes that involved subjecting the mixtures to high heat and mixing in lead to decrease the melting temperature. Statement4: Thus, han purple was probably discovered by fortuitous accident during glass production.
Premise1: Chemical analysis shows that most of the known fragments of both han purple and the white glass were produced within a small geographical radius.
Premise2: The white glass is found in more surviving artifacts from the qin and han dynasties than han purple is.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: How the pigment known as han purple was synthesized by the ancient chinese of the qin and han dynasties has puzzled scientists. Statement2: The chinese chemists employed the same chemical ingredients used for han purple in the production of a common type of white glass during that period. Statement3: Both were produced in processes that involved subjecting the mixtures to high heat and mixing in lead to decrease the melting temperature. Statement4: Thus, although chemical analysis shows that most of the known fragments of both han purple and the white glass maybe were not produced within a small geographical radius, han purple was probably discovered by fortuitous accident during glass production.

input_info.O: Premise1: People's efforts to modify their weight to conform to a given range would not damage their health enough to decrease their overall life expectancies.

Argument: Statement1: Newspaper editors should not allow reporters to write the headlines for their own stories. Argument: Statement1: Archaeologists working in the andes mountains recently excavated a buried 4,000-year-old temple containing structures that align with a stone carving on a distant hill to indicate the direction of the rising sun at the summer solstice. Statement3: Since the local mythology represents the fox as teaching people how to cultivate and irrigate plants, the ancient andeans may have built the temple as a religious representation of the fox.

Argument: Statement1: The format of network television news programs generally allows advocates of a point of view only 30 seconds to convey their message. Statement2: Consequently, regular watchers become accustomed to thinking of issues in terms only of slogans and catch phrases, and so the expectation of careful discussion of public issues gradually disappears from their awareness. Statement3: The format of newspaper stories, on the other hand, leads readers to pursue details of stories headed by the most important facts and so has the opposite effect on regular readers -- that of maintaining the expectation of careful discussion of public issues. Statement4: Therefore, in contrast to regular newspaper reading, regular watching of network television news programs increases the tendency to think of public issues in oversimplified terms.
Premise1: In network television news reports, it is not usual for a reporter to offer additional factual evidence and background information to develop a story in which opposing views are presented briefly by their advocates.
Premise2: It is not possible for television to present public issues in a way that allows for the nuanced presentation of diverse views and a good-faith interchange between advocates of opposing views.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: The format of network television news programs generally allows advocates of a point of view only 30 seconds to convey their message. Statement2: Consequently, regular watchers become accustomed to thinking of issues in terms only of slogans and catch phrases, and so the expectation of careful discussion of public issues gradually disappears from their awareness. Statement3: The format of newspaper stories, on the other hand, leads readers to pursue details of stories headed by the most important facts and so has the opposite effect on regular readers -- that of maintaining the expectation of careful discussion of public issues. Statement4: Therefore, in contrast to regular newspaper reading, regular watching of network television news programs increases the tendency to think of public issues without multiple perspectives.

input_info.Q: The argument assumes which one of the following?
input_info.Om: Premise2: It is not possible for television to present public issues in a way that allows for the nuanced presentation of diverse views and a good-faith interchange between advocates of opposing views.
input_info.O: Premise1: In network television news reports, it is not usual for a reporter to offer additional factual evidence and background information to develop a story in which opposing views are presented briefly by their advocates.
input_info.P: Statement1: The format of network television news programs generally allows advocates of a point of view only 30 seconds to convey their message. Statement2: Consequently, regular watchers become accustomed to thinking of issues in terms only of slogans and catch phrases, and so the expectation of careful discussion of public issues gradually disappears from their awareness. Statement3: The format of newspaper stories, on the other hand, leads readers to pursue details of stories headed by the most important facts and so has the opposite effect on regular readers -- that of maintaining the expectation of careful discussion of public issues. Statement4: Therefore, in contrast to regular newspaper reading, regular watching of network television news programs increases the tendency to think of public issues in oversimplified terms.

Argument: Statement1: Ecologist : smallpox, one of the worst diseases ever to afflict humans, has in some outbreaks killed as much as 50 percent of local populations. Statement2: The last known surviving cultures of variola -- the smallpox virus -- are confined to two high-security laboratories. Some scientists are anxious to destroy the remaining variola cultures, to which humans are susceptible. Statement3: Research on the cultures, however, may someday lead to important benefits for humans, and so the cultures should not be destroyed.
Premise1: It is more likely that the virus, if left available to researchers, will lead to an important medical breakthrough than that the virus will be accidentally released from the laboratory.
Premise2: Smallpox has killed millions of humans over the centuries, and when it reaches the stage of an epidemic it is extremely difficult to eradicate.

Statement2: The last known surviving cultures of variola -- the smallpox virus -- are confined to two high-security laboratories. Some scientists are anxious to destroy the remaining variola cultures, to which humans are susceptible. Statement4: Research on the cultures, although, may someday lead to important benefits for humans, the cultures should be destroyed.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Smallpox has killed millions of humans over the centuries, and when it reaches the stage of an epidemic it is extremely difficult to eradicate.
input_info.O: Premise1: It is more likely that the virus, if left available to researchers, will lead to an important medical breakthrough than that the virus will be accidentally released from the laboratory.

Argument: Statement1: Nuclear reactors are sometimes built in" geologically quiet" regions, so called by geologists because such regions are distant from plate boundaries and contain only minor faults. Statement2: Since no minor fault in a geologically quiet region produces an earthquake more often than once in any given 100,000-year period, it follows that of all potential nuclear reactor sites in such a region, those that are least likely to be struck by an earthquake are ones located near a fault that has produced an earthquake within living memory.
Premise1: In a geologically quiet region, every potential nuclear reactor site is near at least one minor fault.
Premise2: Geologically quiet regions are the least dangerous regions in which to build nuclear reactors.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Nuclear reactors are all built in" geologically quiet" regions, so called by geologists because such regions are distant from plate boundaries and contain only minor or no faults. Statement2: Since no minor fault in a geologically quiet region produces an earthquake more often than once in any given 100,000-year period, it follows that of all potential nuclear reactor sites in such a region, those that are least likely to be struck by an earthquake are ones located near a fault that has produced an earthquake within living memory.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Geologically quiet regions are the least dangerous regions in which to build nuclear reactors.
input_info.O: Premise1: In a geologically quiet region, every potential nuclear reactor site is near at least one minor fault.

Argument: Statement1: The sense of delayed gratification, of working now for later pleasure, has helped shape the economic behavior of our society. Statement2: However, that sense is no longer nurtured as consistently in our children as it once was. Statement3: For example, it used to take a bit of patience to put together the toys that children got in cereal boxes ; now the toys come from the boxes whole.
Premise1: The toys that used to come in cereal boxes were put together by the same children who played with them.
Premise2: The toys in cereal boxes have changed partly because the economic conditions of our society have improved.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: The sense of delayed gratification, of working now for later pleasure, had helped shape the economic behavior of our society. Statement2: However, that sense is no longer nurtured as consistently in our children as it once was. Statement3: For example, it used to take a bit of patience for parents to put together the toys that children got in cereal boxes ; now the toys come from the boxes whole.

input_info.Q: Which of the following is an assumption of the passage above?
input_info.Om: Premise2: The toys in cereal boxes have changed partly because the economic conditions of our society have improved.
input_info.O: Premise1: The toys that used to come in cereal boxes were put together by the same children who played with them.
input_info.P: Statement1: The sense of delayed gratification, of working now for later pleasure, has helped shape the economic behavior of our society. Statement2: However, that sense is no longer nurtured as consistently in our children as it once was. Statement3: For example, it used to take a bit of patience to put together the toys that children got in cereal boxes ; now the toys come from the boxes whole.

Argument: Statement1: Economist : during a recession, a company can cut personnel costs either by laying off some employees without reducing the wages of remaining employees or by reducing the wages of all employees without laying off anyone. Statement2: Thus, when companies must reduce personnel costs during recessions, they are likely to lay off employees.

Premise2: Some companies that have laid off employees during recessions have had difficulty finding enough qualified employees once economic growth resumed.

input_info.O: Premise1: Employee morale is usually the primary concern driving companies' decisions about whether to lay off employees or to reduce their wages.

Argument: Statement1: After an area has been hit by a natural disaster, there is often a great demand for plywood for repairing damaged homes. Statement2: Retailers in the area often raise prices on new shipments of plywood to well above their predisaster prices, and some people denounce these retailers for taking advantage of a disaster to make more money on each sheet of plywood they sell. Statement3: In fact, however, these retailers do not make more money on each sheet of plywood than before the disaster, because transporting the plywood into devastated areas is difficult and expensive, and therefore the plywood's cost to retailers is higher than it was before the disaster.
Premise1: The increase in the prices charged by retailers for plywood following a natural disaster does not exceed the increase in cost to those retailers.
Premise2: Retailers must pay the full amount of any increase in shipping costs.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: After an area has been hit by a natural disaster, there is often a great demand for plywood for repairing damaged homes. Statement2: Retailers in the area often raise prices on new shipments of plywood to well above their predisaster prices, and some people denounce these retailers for taking advantage of a disaster to make more money on each sheet of plywood they sell. Statement3: In fact, however, these retailers do not make more money on each sheet of plywood than before the disaster, because the increase fee of transporting the plywood into devastated areas is the same as the increased price, and therefore the plywood's profit to retailers is same as it was before the disaster.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Retailers must pay the full amount of any increase in shipping costs.
input_info.O: Premise1: The increase in the prices charged by retailers for plywood following a natural disaster does not exceed the increase in cost to those retailers.

Argument: Statement1: On the nights immediately following the mysterious tunguska event, which destroyed a tract of siberian wilderness in 1908, eyewitnesses reported seeing noctilucent clouds -- brilliant night-visible clouds made up of ice particles that form rarely and only at very high altitudes. Statement3: This shows that it was a comet impact and not the impact of an asteroid that caused the destruction in siberia.

Premise2: Noctilucent clouds are visible for many consecutive nights following the release of water vapor into the upper atmosphere.

Statement3: This shows that in many consecutive nights after the tunguska event people can observe noctilucent clouds in siberia.

Argument: Statement1: In some jurisdictions, lawmakers have instituted sentencing guidelines that mandate a penalty for theft that is identical to the one they have mandated for bribery. Argument: Statement1: Biologist : marine animals known as box jellyfish have eyes with well-formed lenses capable of producing sharp images that reveal fine detail. Statement3: This example shows that jellyfish's retinas have become vestigial, which cannot receive a clear image.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Box jellyfish developed from jellyfish whose retinas received clear images.
input_info.O: Premise1: Box jellyfish have a need to detect prominent features of objects but not fine details.

Argument: Statement1: Scientists have long thought that omega-3 fatty acids in fish oil tend to lower blood cholesterol and strongly suspected that a diet that includes a modest amount of fish would provide substantial health benefits. Argument: Statement1: A hospital should not be entitled to patent the research breakthroughs of its resident physicians. Statement2: Hospitals, as sources of medical advancement, should encourage the free flow of ideas and the general dissemination of medical knowledge. Yet a hospital that retains the right to patent the breakthroughs of its resident physicians has a motive to suppress information about the discovery of a potentially valuable medicine until the patent for it has been secured. Statement3: Clearly, suppressing information concerning such discoveries is incompatible with the hospital's obligation to promote the general dissemination of medical knowledge.

Premise2: Hospitals are the only institutions that have an obligation to serve as a source of medical advancement.

Statement4: Clearly, suppressing information concerning such discoveries is incompatible with the institution's obligation to promote the general dissemination of medical knowledge.

input_info.O: Premise1: Hospitals that have a motive to suppress information concerning research breakthroughs by their resident physicians will occasionally act on that motive.

Argument: Statement1: John of worcester, an english monk, recorded the sighting, on december 8, 1128, of two unusually large sunspots. Five days later a brilliant aurora borealis ( northern lights ) was observed in southern korea. Statement2: Sunspot activity is typically followed by the appearance of an aurora borealis, after a span of time that averages five days. Statement3: Thus, the korean sighting helps to confirm john of worcester's sighting.
Premise1: Only heavy sunspot activity could have resulted in an aurora borealis viewable at a latitude as low as that of korea.
Premise2: An aurora borealis can sometimes occur even when there has been no significant sunspot activity in the previous week.

Five days later a brilliant aurora borealis ( northern lights ) was observed in southern korea. Statement4: However, the korean sighting doesn't help to confirm john of worcester's sighting.

input_info.Om: Premise2: An aurora borealis can sometimes occur even when there has been no significant sunspot activity in the previous week.

Statement3: Thus, the korean sighting helps to confirm john of worcester's sighting.

Argument: Statement1: Gortland has long been narrowly self-sufficient in both grain and meat. Argument: Statement1: Even though trading in ivory has been outlawed by international agreement, some piano makers still use ivory, often obtained illegally, to cover piano keys. Statement2: Recently, experts have devised a synthetic ivory that, unlike earlier ivory substitutes, has found favor with concert pianists throughout the world. Statement3: But because piano makers have never been major consumers of ivory, the development of the synthetic ivory will therefore probably do little to help curb the killing of elephants, from whose tusks most natural ivory is obtained.
Premise1: The most common use for natural ivory is in ornamental carvings, which are prized not only for the quality of their workmanship but also for the authenticity of their materials.
Premise2: The new synthetic ivory can be manufactured to resemble in color and surface texture any of the various types of natural ivory that have commercial uses.

Statement2: Recently, experts have devised a synthetic ivory that, unlike earlier ivory substitutes, has found favor with concert pianists throughout the world. Statement3: And the costs of new synthetic ivory is the same as natural ivory, so the new synthetic ivory can be substitute for the natural that have commercial uses.

Argument: Statement1: Rhizobium bacteria living in the roots of bean plants or other legumes produce fixed nitrogen, which is one of the essential plant nutrients and which for nonlegume crops, such as wheat, normally must be supplied by applications of nitrogen-based fertilizer. Argument: Statement1: Patel : it is often thought that direct experience, unlike language and culture, can always serve as common ground for communication among human beings. Statement2: But people from different cultures inhabit different sensory worlds. Statement3: Because selective screening of sensory data admits some perceptions while filtering out others, one person's experience, perceived through one set of culturally patterned sensory screens, is quite different from what anyone from another culture would experience when encountering the same sensory data.
Premise1: No two people from different cultures have the same sensory screens.
Premise2: Two people from the same culture sometimes have different sensory screens.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Patel : it is often thought that direct experience, unlike language and culture, can always serve as common ground for communication among human beings. Statement2: But different people inhabit different sensory worlds. Statement3: Because selective screening of sensory data admits some perceptions while filtering out others, one person's experience, perceived through one set of patterned sensory screens, is probably different from what anyone from the same culture would experience when encountering the same sensory data.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption required by patel's argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Two people from the same culture sometimes have different sensory screens.
input_info.O: Premise1: No two people from different cultures have the same sensory screens.
input_info.P: Statement1: Patel : it is often thought that direct experience, unlike language and culture, can always serve as common ground for communication among human beings. Statement2: But people from different cultures inhabit different sensory worlds. Statement3: Because selective screening of sensory data admits some perceptions while filtering out others, one person's experience, perceived through one set of culturally patterned sensory screens, is quite different from what anyone from another culture would experience when encountering the same sensory data.

Argument: Statement1: Politician : the cohesion of a society depends on its members'accepting a set of basic principles. Statement2: Any society, therefore, that allows schools to present the society's set of basic principles as simply one of several alternatives, with the suggestion that students may choose which to accept on the basis of the principles'worth, is inviting its own demise.

Premise2: Unless people believe that they have freely chosen to adopt the principles that govern their societies, they will tend to repudiate these principles.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Unless people believe that they have freely chosen to adopt the principles that govern their societies, they will tend to repudiate these principles.
input_info.O: Premise1: Given the chance to assess the merits of the principles governing their societies, individuals will rarely find those principles acceptable.

input_info.O: Premise1: At least one of the european vampire myths that predated stoker's book did not portray vampires as able to turn into bats.
input_info.P: Statement1: Bram stoker's 1897 novel dracula portrayed vampires -- the" undead" who roam at night to suck the blood of living people -- as able to turn into bats. As a result of the pervasive influence of this novel, many people now assume that a vampire's being able to turn into a bat is an essential part of vampire myths. Statement2: However, this assumption is false, for vampire myths existed in europe long before stoker's book.

Argument: Statement1: Campaigning for election to provincial or state office frequently requires that a candidate spend much time and energy catering to the interests of national party officials who can help the candidate to win office. Statement2: The elected officials who campaign for reelection while they are in office thus often fail to serve the interests of their local consistencies.

Premise2: The interests of local constituencies are well served only by elected officials who do not cater to the interests of national party officials.

Argument: Statement1: Stage performances are judged to be realistic to the degree that actors reproduce on stage the behaviors generally associated by audiences with the emotional states of the characters portrayed. Statement2: Traditional actors imitate those behaviors, whereas method actors, through recollection of personal experience, actually experience the same emotions that their characters are meant to be experiencing. Statement3: Audiences will therefore judge the performances of method actors to be more realistic than the performances of traditional actors.
Premise1: The behavior that results when a method actor feels a certain emotion will conform to the behavior that is generally associated by audiences with that emotion.
Premise2: Performances based on an actor's own experience of emotional states are more likely to affect an audience's emotions than are performances based on imitations of the behaviors generally associated with those emotional states.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Stage performances are judged to be realistic to the degree that actors reproduce on stage the behaviors generally associated by audiences with the emotional states of the characters portrayed. Statement2: Traditional actors imitate those behaviors, whereas method actors, through recollection of personal experience, actually experience the same emotions that their characters are meant to be experiencing. Statement3: Audiences will therefore judge the performances of method actors to affect an audience's emotions more than the performances of traditional actors.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Performances based on an actor's own experience of emotional states are more likely to affect an audience's emotions than are performances based on imitations of the behaviors generally associated with those emotional states.
input_info.O: Premise1: The behavior that results when a method actor feels a certain emotion will conform to the behavior that is generally associated by audiences with that emotion.

Statement3: Audiences will therefore judge the performances of method actors to be more realistic than the performances of traditional actors.

Argument: Statement1: In any field, experience is required for a proficient person to become an expert. Although computers have the ability to store millions of bits of information, the knowledge of human experts, who benefit from the experience of thousands of situations, is not stored within their brains in the form of rules and facts. Statement2: Through experience, a proficient person gradually develops a repertory of model situations that allows an immediate, intuitive response to each new situation. Statement3: This is the hallmark of expertise, and for this reason computerized" expert systems" can not be as good as human experts.
Premise1: The knowledge of human experts cannot be adequately rendered into the type of information that a computer can store.
Premise2: Future advances in computer technology will not render computers capable of sorting through greater amounts of information.

Argument: Statement1: The more sunlight our planet reflects back into space, the cooler the global atmosphere tends to become. Statement2: Snow and ice reflect much more sunlight back into space than do ocean water or land without snow cover. Statement3: Therefore, the greater the area of earth's surface that is covered with snow and ice, the cooler, on average, the global atmosphere is likely to become.
Premise1: Ocean water and land heated by sunlight in turn warm earth's atmosphere.
Premise2: Other factors besides the reflectivity of ice and snow affect the cooling of earth's atmosphere.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: The more sunlight our planet reflects back into space, the cooler the global atmosphere tends to become. Statement2: Snow and ice reflect much more sunlight back into space than do ocean water or land without snow cover. Statement3: However, the area of earth's surface that is covered with snow and ice, make no difference to the global atmosphere.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Other factors besides the reflectivity of ice and snow affect the cooling of earth's atmosphere.
input_info.O: Premise1: Ocean water and land heated by sunlight in turn warm earth's atmosphere.

Statement2: Snow and ice reflect much more sunlight back into space than do ocean water or land without snow cover. Argument: Statement1: Researchers took a group of teenagers who had never smoked and for one year tracked whether they took up smoking and how their mental health changed. Statement2: Since nicotine in cigarettes changes brain chemistry, perhaps thereby affecting mood, it is likely that smoking contributes to depression in teenagers.

Argument: Statement1: Studies show that the most creative engineers get their best and most useful ideas only after doodling and jotting down what turn out to be outlandish ideas. Now that many engineers do their work with computers instead of on paper, however, doodling is becoming much less common, and some experts fear that the result will be fewer creative and useful engineering ideas. Statement2: These experts argue that this undesirable consequence would be avoided if computer programs for engineering work included simulated notepads that would allow engineers to suspend their" serious"work on the computer, type up outlandish ideas, and then quickly return to their original work.
Premise1: The physical act of working on paper is not essential in providing engineers with the benefits that can be gained by doodling.
Premise2: No engineers who work with computers keep paper and pencils near their computers in order to doodle and jot down ideas.

output: Statement1: Studies show that the most creative engineers get their best and most useful ideas only after doodling and jotting down on paper what turn out to be outlandish ideas. Statement3: These experts argue that this undesirable consequence would be avoided if keeping paper and pencils near their computers that would allow engineers to suspend their" serious"work, write down outlandish ideas, and then quickly return to their original work.

Argument: Statement1: A newly discovered painting seems to be the work of one of two seventeenth-century artists, either the northern german johannes drechen or the frenchman louis birelle, who sometimes painted in the same style as drechen. Statement2: Analysis of the carved picture frame, which has been identified as the painting 's original seventeenth-century frame, showed that it is made of wood found widely in northern germany at the time, but rare in the part of france where birelle lived. Statement3: This shows that the painting is most likely the work of drechen.
Premise1: The frame was made from wood local to the region where the picture was painted.
Premise2: Sometimes a painting so resembles others of its era that no expert is able to confidently decide who painted it.

Statement3: This shows that the painting still can not be decided who painted it.

input_info.O: Premise1: The frame was made from wood local to the region where the picture was painted.

Argument: Statement1: In 1563, in florence's palazzo vecchio, giorgio vasari built in front of an existing wall a new wall on which he painted a mural. Statement2: Investigators recently discovered a gap between vasari's wall and the original, large enough to have preserved anything painted on the original. Statement3: Historians believe that leonardo da vinci had painted, but left unfinished, a mural on the original wall ; some historians had also believed that by 1563 the mural had been destroyed. Statement4: However, it is known that in the late 1560s, when renovating another building, santa marianovella, vasari built a facade over its frescoes, and the frescoes were thereby preserved. Statement5: Thus, leonardo's palazzo vecchio mural probably still exists behind vasari's wall.
Premise1: Vasari probably would not have built the palazzo vecchio wall with a gap behind it except to preserve something behind the new wall.
Premise2: Leonardo would probably have completed the palazzo vecchio mural if he had had the opportunity to do so.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: In 1563, in florence's palazzo vecchio, giorgio vasari built in front of an existing wall a new wall on which he painted a mural. Statement2: Investigators recently discovered a gap between vasari's wall and the original, large enough to have preserved anything painted on the original. Statement3: Historians believe that leonardo da vinci had painted, but left unfinished, a mural on the original wall ; some historians had also believed that by 1563 the mural had been destroyed because of its unfinishment. Statement4: However, it is known that in the late 1560s, when renovating another building, santa marianovella, vasari built a facade over its frescoes, and the frescoes were thereby preserved. Statement5: Thus, leonardo's palazzo vecchio mural probably still exists.

input_info.Q: Which of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Leonardo would probably have completed the palazzo vecchio mural if he had had the opportunity to do so.
input_info.O: Premise1: Vasari probably would not have built the palazzo vecchio wall with a gap behind it except to preserve something behind the new wall.
input_info.P: Statement1: In 1563, in florence's palazzo vecchio, giorgio vasari built in front of an existing wall a new wall on which he painted a mural. Statement2: Investigators recently discovered a gap between vasari's wall and the original, large enough to have preserved anything painted on the original. Statement3: Historians believe that leonardo da vinci had painted, but left unfinished, a mural on the original wall ; some historians had also believed that by 1563 the mural had been destroyed. Statement4: However, it is known that in the late 1560s, when renovating another building, santa marianovella, vasari built a facade over its frescoes, and the frescoes were thereby preserved. Statement5: Thus, leonardo's palazzo vecchio mural probably still exists behind vasari's wall.

input_info.P: Statement1: Columnist : even if the primary purpose of university education is to make students employable, such education should emphasize the liberal arts rather than the more narrow kind of technical training that prepares one for a particular sort of job. Argument: Statement1: In 1974 the speed limit on highways in the united states was reduced to 55 miles per hour in order to save fuel. Statement2: In the first 12 months after the change, the rate of highway fatalities dropped 15 percent, the sharpest one-year drop in history. Over the next 10 years, the fatality rate declined by another 25 percent. Statement3: It follows that the 1974 reduction in the speed limit saved many lives.
Premise1: The fatality rate in highway accidents involving motorists driving faster than 55 miles per hour is much higher than in highway accidents that do not involve motorists driving at such speeds.
Premise2: Motorists are more likely to avoid accidents by matching their speed to that of the surrounding highway traffic than by driving at faster or slower speeds.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: In 1974 the speed limit on highways in the united states was reduced to 55 miles per hour in order to match their speed to surrounding highway traffic. Statement2: In the first 12 months after the change, the rate of highway fatalities dropped 15 percent, the sharpest one-year drop in history. Over the next 10 years, the fatality rate declined by another 25 percent. Statement4: It follows that the 1974 reduction in the speed limit saved many lives.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Motorists are more likely to avoid accidents by matching their speed to that of the surrounding highway traffic than by driving at faster or slower speeds.

Argument: Statement1: At one sitting, a typical doughnut eater consumes 4 doughnuts containing a total of 680 calories and 40 grams of fat. Statement2: The typical bagel eater consumes exactly one bagel, at 500 calories and one or two grams of fat per sitting, though the addition of spreads can raise calorie and fat content to the four-doughnut range. Statement3: Thus, as far as total calorie content is concerned, there is very little difference between what a typical doughnut eater and a typical bagel eater each consumes at one sitting.

Premise2: Most bagel eaters are not fully aware of the calorie and fat content of a bagel.

Statement3: However, as far as total calorie content is concerned, there is very little possibility that bagel eaters are trying to lose weight.

Argument: Statement1: Bacteria from food can survive for several days on the surface of plastic cutting boards, but bacteria can penetrate wooden cutting boards almost immediately, leaving the surface free of contamination. Statement2: Therefore, wooden cutting boards, unlike plastic cutting boards, need not be washed in order to prevent their contaminating food that is cut on them ; wiping them off to remove food debris is sufficient.
Premise1: Bacteria that penetrate into wooden cutting boards do not reemerge on the surface after the cutting boards have been used.
Premise2: Washing plastic cutting boards does not remove all bacteria from the surface.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Bacteria from food can survive for several days on the surface of plastic cutting boards, but bacteria can penetrate wooden cutting boards almost immediately, leaving the surface free of contamination. Statement2: Therefore, wooden cutting boards, unlike plastic cutting boards, could be washed totally clean in order to prevent their contaminating food that is cut on them ; wiping them off to remove food debris is sufficient.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Washing plastic cutting boards does not remove all bacteria from the surface.
input_info.O: Premise1: Bacteria that penetrate into wooden cutting boards do not reemerge on the surface after the cutting boards have been used.

Argument: Statement1: Climatologist : over the coming century, winter temperatures are likely to increase in the rocky mountains due to global warming. Statement2: This will cause a greater proportion of precipitation to fall as rain instead of snow. Statement3: Therefore, the mountain snowpack will probably melt more rapidly and earlier in the season, leading to greater spring flooding and less storable water to meet summer demands.
Premise1: In other mountainous regions after relatively mild winters, the melting of snowpacks has led to greater spring flooding and less storable water, on average, than in those mountainous regions after colder winters.
Premise2: The larger a mountain snowpack is, the greater the amount of spring flooding it is likely to be responsible for producing.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Climatologist : over the coming century, winter temperatures are likely to decrease in the rocky mountains due to global climate change. Statement2: This will cause a greater proportion of precipitation to fall as snow instead of rain. Statement3: Therefore, the mountain snowpack will probably melt more slowly and later in the season, becoming a larger snowpack and less storable water to meet summer demands.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the climatologist's argument?

Argument: Statement1: Most household appliances use electricity only when in use. Statement2: Many microwave ovens, however, have built-in clocks and so use some electricity even when they are not in use. The clocks each consume about 45 kilowatt-hours per year. Statement3: Therefore, households whose microwave oven has no built-in clock use 45 kilowatt-hours per year less, on average, than do comparable households whose microwave oven is otherwise similar but has a built-in clock.
Premise1: Households whose microwave oven does not have a built-in clock are no more likely to have a separate electric clock plugged in than households whose microwave oven has one.
Premise2: Households that do not have a microwave oven use less energy per year, on average, than do households that have a microwave oven.

Statement2: Many microwave ovens, however, have built-in clocks and so use some electricity even when they are not in use. The clocks each consume about 45 kilowatt-hours per year. Statement4: Therefore, households whose do not have microwave spend less money on energy, on average, than do comparable households whose microwave has a built-in clock.

input_info.Q: Which of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Households that do not have a microwave oven use less energy per year, on average, than do households that have a microwave oven.
input_info.O: Premise1: Households whose microwave oven does not have a built-in clock are no more likely to have a separate electric clock plugged in than households whose microwave oven has one.
