Argument: Statement1: Brown dwarfs -- dim red stars that are too cool to burn hydrogen -- are very similar in appearance to red dwarf stars, which are just hot enough to burn hydrogen. Statement2: Stars, when first formed, contain substantial amounts of the element lithium. All stars but the coolest of the brown dwarfs are hot enough to destroy lithium completely by converting it to helium. Statement3: Accordingly, any star found that contains no lithium is not one of these coolest brown dwarfs.
Premise1: None of the coolest brown dwarfs has ever been hot enough to destroy lithium.
Premise2: No stars are more similar in appearance to red dwarfs than are brown dwarfs.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Brown dwarfs -- dim red stars that are too cool to burn hydrogen -- are very similar in appearance to red dwarf stars, which are just hot enough to burn hydrogen. Statement2: Stars, when first formed, contain substantial amounts of the element lithium. All stars but the coolest of the brown dwarfs are hot enough to destroy lithium completely by converting it to helium. Statement4: Accordingly, any star found that contains lithium is very similar in appearance to red dwarfs.

input_info.Q: The argument depends on assuming which one of the following?
input_info.Om: Premise2: No stars are more similar in appearance to red dwarfs than are brown dwarfs.
input_info.O: Premise1: None of the coolest brown dwarfs has ever been hot enough to destroy lithium.
input_info.P: Statement1: Brown dwarfs -- dim red stars that are too cool to burn hydrogen -- are very similar in appearance to red dwarf stars, which are just hot enough to burn hydrogen. Argument: Statement1: Blogger : traditionally, newspapers have taken objectivity to be an essential of good journalism. However, today's newer media are more inclined to try to create a stir with openly partisan reporting. Statement2: This contrast in journalistic standards is best understood in terms of differing business strategies. Statement3: The newer media outlets need to differentiate themselves in a crowded marketplace. Statement4: The standard of objectivity developed primarily among newspapers with no serious rivals, so the most important objective was to avoid offending potential readers.
Premise1: Newspapers have regarded objective reporting as less likely to offend people than openly partisan reporting.
Premise2: People prefer objective reporting to partisan reporting that merely reinforces their own partisan leanings.

Statement3: This contrast in journalistic standards is best understood in terms of differing business strategies. Statement4: The newer media outlets need to differentiate themselves in a crowded marketplace. Statement5: The standard of objectivity developed primarily among newspapers with no serious rivals, so the most important objective was to attract more readers.

input_info.O: Premise1: Newspapers have regarded objective reporting as less likely to offend people than openly partisan reporting.

Argument: Statement1: When storing renaissance oil paintings, museums conform to standards that call for careful control of the surrounding temperature and humidity, with variations confined within narrow margins. Argument: Statement1: Enthusiasm for the use of calculators in the learning of mathematics is misplaced. Statement2: Teachers rightly observe that in some cases calculators enable students to focus on general principles rather than the tedious, largely rote calculations that constitute the application of these principles. But principles are more likely to be remembered when knowledge of them is grounded in habits ingrained by painstaking applications of those principles. Statement3: The very fact that calculators make calculation easier, therefore, makes it reasonable to restrict their use.
Premise1: It is much more important that students retain the knowledge of general principles than that this knowledge be easily acquired.
Premise2: Habits that are acquired by laborious and sometimes tedious practice are not as valuable as those that are painlessly mastered.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Enthusiasm for the use of calculators in the learning of mathematics is good. Statement2: Teachers rightly observe that in some cases calculators enable students to focus on general principles rather than the tedious, largely rote calculations that constitute the application of these principles. Although habbit is more likely to be remembered when knowledge of them is grounded in habits ingrained by painstaking applications of those principles. Statement4: The habbit that using calculators makes calculation easier, therefore, makes caculators reasonable to use.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Habits that are acquired by laborious and sometimes tedious practice are not as valuable as those that are painlessly mastered.
input_info.O: Premise1: It is much more important that students retain the knowledge of general principles than that this knowledge be easily acquired.

Argument: Statement1: Medical research findings are customarily not made public prior to their publication in a medical journal that has had them reviewed by a panel of experts in a process called peer review. Statement2: It is claimed that this practice delays public access to potentially beneficial information that, in extreme instances, could save lives. Statement3: Yet prepublication peer review is the only way to prevent erroneous and therefore potentially harmful information from reaching a public that is ill equipped to evaluate medical claims on its own. Statement4: Therefore, waiting until a medical journal has published the research findings that have passed peer review is the price that must be paid to protect the public from making decisions based on possibly substandard research.

Argument: Statement1: After a hepadnavirus inserts itself into a chromosome of an animal, fragments of the virus are passed on to all of that animal's descendants. Statement3: The fact that these two bird species diverged from each other about 25 million years ago therefore may not mean that the hepadnavirus is at least 25 million years old.

Argument: Statement1: Fire ants from brazil now infest the southern united states. Statement2: Unlike queen fire ants in brazil, two queens in the united states share a nest. Ants from these nests are more aggressive than those from single-queen nests. Statement3: By destroying virtually all insects in the nest area, these aggressive ants gain sole access to food sources, and the ant population skyrockets. Statement4: Since certain predator insects in brazil limit the fire-ant population there, importing such predator insects into the united states would be of overall benefit to the environment by stopping the increase of the fire-ant population in the united states.
Premise1: The predator insects would stop the increase of the ant population before the ants spread to states that are farther north.
Premise2: The imported insects would not prove more damaging to the environment in the united states than are the fire ants themselves.

Statement5: Although certain predator insects in brazil limit the fire-ant population there, importing such predator insects into the united states would be a huge damage to the environment by stopping the increase of the fire-ant population in the united states.

Argument: Statement1: When volcanic lava solidifies, it becomes uniformly magnetized in the direction in which the earth's magnetic field points. There are significant differences in the direction of magnetization among solidified lava flows from different volcanoes that erupted at different times over the past several million years. Statement2: Therefore, it must be that the direction of the earth's magnetic field has changed over time. Statement3: Since lava flows differing by thousands of years in age often have very similar directions of magnetization, the change in the direction of the earth's magnetic field must take place very gradually over hundreds of thousands of years.
Premise1: Not all solidified lava has changed the direction of its magnetization unpredictably
Premise2: As lava flows down the side of a volcano, it picks up magnetized rocks

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: When volcanic lava solidifies, it becomes uniformly magnetized in the direction in which the earth's magnetic field points. There are significant differences in the direction of magnetization among solidified lava flows from different volcanoes that erupted at different times over the past several million years. Statement3: Therefore, it must be that the direction of the earth's magnetic field has changed over time. Statement4: Although lava flows differing by thousands of years in age often have very similar directions of magnetization, the change in the direction of the earth's magnetic field may not take place very gradually over hundreds of thousands of years.

Argument: Statement1: The stated goal of the government's funding program for the arts is to encourage the creation of works of artistic excellence. Statement2: Senator beton claims, however, that a government-funded artwork can never reflect the independent artistic conscience of the artist because artists, like anyone else who accepts financial support, will inevitably try to please those who control the distribution of that support. Statement3: Senator beton concludes that government funding of the arts not only is a burden on taxpayers but also can not lead to the creation of works of true artistic excellence.
Premise1: A contemporary work of art that does not reflect the independent artistic conscience of the artist cannot be a work of true artistic excellence.
Premise2: Distribution of government funds for the arts is based on a broad agreement as to what constitutes artistic excellence.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: The stated goal of the government's funding program for the arts is to encourage the creation of works of artistic excellence. Statement2: Senator beton claims that a government-funded artwork can never reflect the independent artistic conscience of the artist but artists, like anyone else who accepts financial support, will inevitably try to please those who control the distribution of that support. Statement3: Senator beton concludes that, thus, government funding of the arts is a burden on taxpayers but can lead to the creation of works of true artistic excellence.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Distribution of government funds for the arts is based on a broad agreement as to what constitutes artistic excellence.
input_info.O: Premise1: A contemporary work of art that does not reflect the independent artistic conscience of the artist cannot be a work of true artistic excellence.

Statement3: Senator beton concludes that government funding of the arts not only is a burden on taxpayers but also can not lead to the creation of works of true artistic excellence.

Argument: Statement1: Public health experts have waged a long-standing educational campaign to get people to eat more vegetables, which are known to help prevent cancer. Statement2: Unfortunately, the campaign has had little impact on people's diets. Statement3: The reason is probably that many people simply dislike the taste of most vegetables. Statement4: Thus, the campaign would probably be more effective if it included information on ways to make vegetables more appetizing.

Premise2: Some ways of making vegetables more appetizing diminish vegetables' ability to help prevent cancer.

Please write the modified argument below:

Statement2: Unfortunately, the campaign has had little impact on people's diets. Statement3: The reason is probably that many people simply dislike the taste of most vegetables. Statement4: However, the campaign would probably be less meaningful if it included information on ways to make vegetables more appetizing.

Argument: Statement1: Art historian : successful forgeries tend to be those most recently painted. Statement4: As a result, a majority of forgeries are identified as such at least twenty-five years after their creation.

Argument: Statement1: Modern flamingos derive their pink coloration from pigments stored in tiny shrimp that they filter from shallow, salty waters. The shrimp get this pigment from tiny red algae that they filter through their leg bristles. Statement2: In the jurassic period ( about 200 million years ago ), both algae and shrimp were an excellent source of food for any larger animal equipped to sieve them out of the water through an anatomical strainer. The argentine pterodactyl possessed a row of thin, bristlelike teeth through which it pumped water, straining out any tiny food particles in the process. Statement3: Thus, because it was able to filter both algae and shrimp, it is reasonable to conclude that the pterodactyl acquired a pink coloration.
Premise1: The argentine pterodactyl's habitat included shallow seas that were particularly rich in red algae and shrimp.
Premise2: If the argentine pterodactyl did not eat a diet containing red algae, its color was determined by factors other than diet.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Modern flamingos derive their pink coloration from pigments stored in tiny shrimp that they filter from shallow, salty waters. The shrimp get this pigment from tiny red algae that they filter through their leg bristles. Statement3: In the jurassic period ( about 200 million years ago ), both algae and shrimp were an excellent source of food for any larger animal except the argentine pterodactyl equipped to sieve them out of the water through an anatomical strainer. The argentine pterodactyl possessed a row of thin, bristlelike teeth through which it pumped water, straining out any tiny food particles in the process. Statement5: Thus, because it was able to filter both algae and shrimp, it is reasonable to conclude that the pterodactyl may acquired a pink coloration.

input_info.Om: Premise2: If the argentine pterodactyl did not eat a diet containing red algae, its color was determined by factors other than diet.
input_info.O: Premise1: The argentine pterodactyl's habitat included shallow seas that were particularly rich in red algae and shrimp.
input_info.P: Statement1: Modern flamingos derive their pink coloration from pigments stored in tiny shrimp that they filter from shallow, salty waters. The shrimp get this pigment from tiny red algae that they filter through their leg bristles. Statement2: In the jurassic period ( about 200 million years ago ), both algae and shrimp were an excellent source of food for any larger animal equipped to sieve them out of the water through an anatomical strainer. The argentine pterodactyl possessed a row of thin, bristlelike teeth through which it pumped water, straining out any tiny food particles in the process. Statement3: Thus, because it was able to filter both algae and shrimp, it is reasonable to conclude that the pterodactyl acquired a pink coloration.

Argument: Statement1: Until now, only injectable vaccines against influenza have been available. Statement2: Parents are reluctant to subject children to the pain of injections, but adults, who are at risk of serious complications from influenza, are commonly vaccinated. Statement3: A new influenza vaccine, administered painlessly in a nasal spray, is effective for children. However, since children seldom develop serious complications from influenza, no significant public health benefit would result from widespread vaccination of children using the nasal spray.
Premise1: Adults do not contract influenza primarily from children who have influenza.
Premise2: The injectable vaccine is affordable for all adults.

Please write the modified argument below:

Statement2: Parents are reluctant to subject children to the pain of injections, but adults, who can afford the injectable vaccine, are commonly vaccinated. Statement3: A new influenza vaccine, administered painlessly in a nasal spray, is much inexpensive and effective for children. However, since children seldom develop serious complications from influenza, no significant public health benefit would result from widespread vaccination using the nasal spray.

input_info.Om: Premise2: The injectable vaccine is affordable for all adults.
input_info.O: Premise1: Adults do not contract influenza primarily from children who have influenza.

Argument: Statement1: Eight large craters run in a long straight line across a geographical region. Argument: Statement1: Ethicist : studies have documented the capacity of placebos to reduce pain in patients who believe that they are receiving beneficial drugs. Statement2: Some doctors say that they administer placebos because medically effective treatment reinforced by the placebo effect sometimes helps patients recover faster than good treatment alone. Statement3: But administering placebos is nonetheless ethically questionable, for even if a placebo benefits a patient, a doctor might, for example, have prescribed it just to give the patient satisfaction that something was being done.
Premise1: The motivation for administering a placebo can be relevant to the ethical justification for doing so.
Premise2: The pain relief produced by the placebo effect justifies the deception involved in administering a placebo.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Ethicist : studies have documented the capacity of placebos to reduce pain in patients who believe that they are receiving beneficial drugs. Statement2: Some doctors say that they administer placebos because medically effective treatment reinforced by the placebo effect sometimes helps patients recover faster than good treatment alone. Statement3: Therefore administering placebos can not be ethically questionable, for a placebo benefits a patient, a doctor might, for example, have prescribed it just to give the patient pain relief that something was being done.

input_info.Q: The ethicist's argument depends on which one of the following assumptions?
input_info.Om: Premise2: The pain relief produced by the placebo effect justifies the deception involved in administering a placebo.
input_info.O: Premise1: The motivation for administering a placebo can be relevant to the ethical justification for doing so.
input_info.P: Statement1: Ethicist : studies have documented the capacity of placebos to reduce pain in patients who believe that they are receiving beneficial drugs. Argument: Statement1: Red admiral butterflies fly in a highly irregular fashion, constantly varying their speed, wing strokes, and flight path. Statement2: While predators avoid poisonous butterfly species, nonpoisonous butterflies like the red admiral need to elude predators to survive. Statement3: Scientists therefore hypothesize that the red admiral's flight style, which is clearly not energy efficient, evolved as a means of avoiding predators.
Premise1: No species of poisonous butterfly has an irregular flight style like that of the red admiral.
Premise2: It is much more energy efficient for butterflies to fly in an irregular fashion than it is for heavier varieties of insects.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Red admiral butterflies fly in a highly irregular fashion, constantly varying their speed, wing strokes, and flight path. Statement2: While predators avoid poisonous butterfly species, nonpoisonous butterflies like the red admiral need to use energy efficiently to survive. Statement3: Scientists therefore hypothesize that the red admiral's flight style, which is clearly energy efficient, may not evolved as a means of avoiding predators.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the support for the scientists' hypothesis?
input_info.Om: Premise2: It is much more energy efficient for butterflies to fly in an irregular fashion than it is for heavier varieties of insects.
input_info.O: Premise1: No species of poisonous butterfly has an irregular flight style like that of the red admiral.
input_info.P: Statement1: Red admiral butterflies fly in a highly irregular fashion, constantly varying their speed, wing strokes, and flight path. Argument: Statement1: A survey of address changes filed with post offices and driver's license bureaus over the last ten years has established that households moving out of the city of weston outnumbered households moving into the city two to one. Statement2: Therefore, we can expect that next year's census, which counts all residents regardless of age, will show that the population of weston has declined since the last census ten years ago.
Premise1: Most adults moving out of weston were parents who had children living with them, whereas most adults remaining in or moving into the city were older people who lived alone.
Premise2: Many people moving into weston failed to notify either the post office or the driver's license bureau that they had moved to the city.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: A survey of address changes filed with post offices and driver's license bureaus over the last ten years has established that households moving out of the city of weston outnumbered households moving into the city two to one. Statement2: Lowering prices of dvds and releasing them sooner would mitigate piracy's negative effect on film industry profits.

Argument: Statement1: Until now, only injectable vaccines against influenza have been available. A new vaccine administered in a nasal spray has proven effective in preventing influenza in children. Premise2: The new vaccine uses the same mechanism to ward off influenza as injectable vaccines do.

Statement4: Since children are significantly same as older adults to contract and spread influenza, making the new vaccine widely available for children will have the same effect as the injectable vaccines.

input_info.Om: Premise2: The new vaccine uses the same mechanism to ward off influenza as injectable vaccines do.

Statement2: To maintain the ship's proper stability, water must be pumped out of these tanks when cargo is loaded and into them when cargo is unloaded. As a result, sea creatures often get into the tanks and are then inadvertently deposited into new habitats, where they can wreak ecological havoc. Statement3: One viable way of addressing this problem would be to empty and then immediately refill the tanks in midocean, since midocean creatures and coastal sea creatures usually can not survive in one another's habitats.
Premise1: There are at least some oceangoing ships whose stability could be adequately maintained while emptying and refilling their ballast tanks in midocean.
Premise2: Sea creatures have rarely, if ever, wreaked ecological havoc in a new habitat, unless they have been able to survive in that habitat after having been deposited there by oceangoing ships.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: All oceangoing ships carry seawater ballast tanks whose weight improves stability. Statement2: To maintain the ship's proper stability, water must be pumped out of these tanks when cargo is loaded and into them when cargo is unloaded. As a result, sea creatures often get into the tanks and are then inadvertently deposited into new habitats, where they can wreak ecological havoc. Statement4: One viable way of addressing this problem would be to empty and then immediately refill the tanks in midocean, since doing these operations will not affect the stability and midocean creatures and coastal sea creatures usually can not survive in one another's habitats.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption the argument requires?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Sea creatures have rarely, if ever, wreaked ecological havoc in a new habitat, unless they have been able to survive in that habitat after having been deposited there by oceangoing ships.
input_info.O: Premise1: There are at least some oceangoing ships whose stability could be adequately maintained while emptying and refilling their ballast tanks in midocean.
input_info.P: Statement1: All oceangoing ships carry seawater ballast tanks whose weight improves stability. Statement2: To maintain the ship's proper stability, water must be pumped out of these tanks when cargo is loaded and into them when cargo is unloaded. As a result, sea creatures often get into the tanks and are then inadvertently deposited into new habitats, where they can wreak ecological havoc. Argument: Statement1: Advertisement : when your car 's engine is running at its normal operating temperature, any major brand of motor oil will protect it about as well as tuff does. Premise2: Tuff motor oil is manufactured at only one refinery and shipped from there to all markets.

Statement3: So, if you want your car 's engine to have maximum protection, you should use tuff.

Argument: Statement1: Among the many temptations of the digital age, manipulation of photographs has proved particularly troublesome for science. Statement2: Recently, a journal of cellular biology began using a software tool to examine the digital images submitted along with articles for publication. Statement3: Clearly, scientific fraud is a widespread problem among the authors submitting to that journal.

Premise2: Scientific fraud is possible in the field of cellular biology only if the research is documented with digital images.

Argument: Statement1: Psychology researchers observed that parents feel emotion while singing to their infants. The researchers concluded that their hypothesis was correct. Statement2: The researchers hypothesized that this emotion noticeably affects the sound of the singing. Statement3: To test this hypothesis the parents were recorded while singing to their infants and while singing with no infant present. They were instructed to make the two renditions as similar as possible. Statement4: These recordings were then played for psychologists who had not observed the recordings being made. For 80 percent of the recordings, these psychologists were able to correctly identify, by listening alone, which recordings were of parents singing to their children.
Premise1: When a person feels emotion, that emotion provokes involuntary physiological responses that affect the vocal cords and lungs.
Premise2: A separate study by the same researchers found that parents feel more emotion when singing to their own children than when singing to other children.

Premise2: Countries surrounding country x will reduce the amount of pollution that their factories release into the air and water.

Argument: Statement1: Ordinary mountain sickness, a common condition among mountain climbers, and one from which most people can recover, is caused by the characteristic shortage of oxygen in the atmosphere at high altitudes. Cerebral edema, a rarer disruption of blood circulation in the brain that quickly becomes life-threatening if not correctly treated from its onset, can also be caused by a shortage of oxygen. Statement2: Since the symptoms of cerebral edema resemble those of ordinary mountain sickness, cerebral edema is especially dangerous at high altitudes.
Premise1: The treatment for ordinary mountain sickness differs from the treatment for cerebral edema.
Premise2: Cerebral edema can cause those who suffer from it to slip into a coma within a few hours.

Statement3: Although the symptoms of cerebral edema partly resemble those of ordinary mountain sickness, cerebral edema isn't especially dangerous at high altitudes.

Argument: Statement1: Zoologist : plants preferentially absorb heavy nitrogen from rainwater. Statement2: Heavy nitrogen consequently becomes concentrated in the tissues of herbivores, and animals that eat meat in turn exhibit even higher concentrations of heavy nitrogen in their bodily tissues. We compared bone samples from european cave bears of the ice age with blood samples from present-day bears fed meat-enriched diets, and the levels of heavy nitrogen present in these samples were identical. Statement3: Thus, the prehistoric european cave bears were not exclusively herbivores.
Premise1: Bone samples from present-day bears fed meat-enriched diets exhibit the same levels of heavy nitrogen as do their blood samples.
Premise2: The level of heavy nitrogen in the bones of any bear fed a meat-enriched diet is the same as that in the bones of any other meat-eating bear.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Zoologist : plants preferentially absorb heavy nitrogen from rainwater. Statement2: Heavy nitrogen consequently becomes concentrated in the tissues of herbivores, and animals that eat meat in turn exhibit even higher concentrations of heavy nitrogen in their bodily tissues. We compared bone samples from normal meat-eating bear with blood samples from present-day bears fed meat-enriched diets, and the levels of heavy nitrogen present in these samples were identical. Statement4: Thus, how much meat a bear eats doesn't affect the level of heavy nitrogen in the bones.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following, if true, would most strengthen the zoologist's argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: The level of heavy nitrogen in the bones of any bear fed a meat-enriched diet is the same as that in the bones of any other meat-eating bear.
input_info.O: Premise1: Bone samples from present-day bears fed meat-enriched diets exhibit the same levels of heavy nitrogen as do their blood samples.
input_info.P: Statement1: Zoologist : plants preferentially absorb heavy nitrogen from rainwater. Statement2: Heavy nitrogen consequently becomes concentrated in the tissues of herbivores, and animals that eat meat in turn exhibit even higher concentrations of heavy nitrogen in their bodily tissues. We compared bone samples from european cave bears of the ice age with blood samples from present-day bears fed meat-enriched diets, and the levels of heavy nitrogen present in these samples were identical. Statement3: Thus, the prehistoric european cave bears were not exclusively herbivores.

Argument: Statement1: One variety of partially biodegradable plastic beverage container is manufactured from small bits of plastic bound together by a degradable bonding agent such as cornstarch. Statement2: Since only the bonding agent degrades, leaving the small bits of plastic, no less plastic refuse per container is produced when such containers are discarded than when comparable nonbiodegradable containers are discarded.
Premise1: The partially biodegradable plastic beverage containers are made with more plastic than comparable nonbiodegradable ones in order to compensate for the weakening effect of the bonding agents.
Premise2: Many consumers are ecology-minded and prefer to buy a product sold in the partially biodegradable plastic beverage containers rather than in nonbiodegradable containers, even if the price is higher.

Statement2: Although only the bonding agent degrades, leaving the small bits of plastic, these partially biodegradable plastic containers have better sales than nonbiodegradable ontainers.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Many consumers are ecology-minded and prefer to buy a product sold in the partially biodegradable plastic beverage containers rather than in nonbiodegradable containers, even if the price is higher.

Argument: Statement1: When exercising the muscles in one's back, it is important, in order to maintain a healthy back, to exercise the muscles on opposite sides of the spine equally. Statement2: After all, balanced muscle development is needed to maintain a healthy back, since the muscles on opposite sides of the spine must pull equally in opposing directions to keep the back in proper alignment and protect the spine.
Premise1: Exercising the muscles on opposite sides of the spine unequally tends to lead to unbalanced muscle development.
Premise2: Muscles on opposite sides of the spine that are equally well developed will be enough to keep the back in proper alignment.

Statement2: After all, balanced and well-developed muscle development is needed to maintain a healthy back, since the back must be healthily maintained to keep the back in proper alignment and protect the spine.

Argument: Statement1: In wareland last year, 16 percent of licensed drivers under 21 and 11 percent of drivers ages 21-24 were in serious accidents. By contrast, only 3 percent of licensed drivers 65 and older were involved in serious accidents. Statement2: These figures clearly show that the greater experience and developed habits of caution possessed by drivers in the 65-and-older group make them far safer behind the wheel than the younger drivers are.
Premise1: Drivers 65 and older do not, on average, drive very many fewer miles per year than drivers 24 and younger.
Premise2: Drivers 65 and older are less likely than are drivers 24 and younger to drive during weather conditions that greatly increase the risk of accidents.

By contrast, only 3 percent of licensed drivers 65 and older were involved in serious accidents. Statement3: These figures clearly show that the licensed drivers 24 and younger are more likely to take the risk while driving for example the bad weather.

Argument: Statement1: Herbalist : many herbal medicines work best when they have a chance to influence the body gently over several months. Statement2: However, many of these herbal medicines have toxic side effects when taken daily for such long periods. Premise2: At least some herbal medicines work less well in achieving their desired effects if one occasionally skips one's usual dose than if one does not.

input_info.Om: Premise2: At least some herbal medicines work less well in achieving their desired effects if one occasionally skips one's usual dose than if one does not.

Argument: Statement1: The more demand there is for something, the easier it is to sell. Statement2: Any junkyard will buy a used car that is less than ten years old, because the parts can easily be resold. However, because there is little demand for car parts that are ten years old or older, junkyards tend not to buy those cars. Statement3: Thus, used cars that are less than ten years old are generally easier to sell than are cars that are ten years old or older.
Premise1: The salability of cars that are ten years old or older is largely a function of the level of demand for their parts.
Premise2: The salability of something is not influenced by any factors other than the level of demand for it.

Statement2: Any junkyard will buy a used car that is less than ten years old, because the parts can easily be resold. However, because there no demand for car parts that are ten years old or older, junkyards will not to buy those cars. Statement4: Thus, used cars that are more than ten years old car can not be sold.

Argument: Statement1: Sociologist : the intended function of news is to give us information on which to act. Statement2: But in a consumer society, news becomes a product to be manufactured and dispensed to the consumer. Statement3: An enormous industry for the production and consumption of news has evolved, and we ingest news with an insatiable appetite. Statement4: Under such circumstances, news is primarily entertaining and can not, therefore, serve its intended function.
Premise1: News that primarily entertains does not give us information on which to act.
Premise2: News that serves its intended function should not be entertaining.

Statement2: But in a consumer society, news becomes a product to be manufactured and dispensed to the consumer. Statement3: An enormous industry for the production and consumption of news has evolved, and we ingest news with an insatiable appetite. Statement4: Under such circumstances, news is entertaining and can not, therefore, serve its intended function.

input_info.Om: Premise2: News that serves its intended function should not be entertaining.
input_info.O: Premise1: News that primarily entertains does not give us information on which to act.

Argument: Statement1: Gartland has long been narrowly self-sufficient in both grain and meat. However, as per capita income in gartland has risen toward the world average, per capita consumption of meat has also risen toward the world average, and it takes several pounds of grain to produce one pound of meat. Statement2: Therefore, since per capita income continues to rise, whereas domestic grain production will not increase, gartland will soon have to import either grain or meat or both.
Premise1: People in gartland who increase their consumption of meat will not radically decrease their consumption of grain.
Premise2: In gartland, neither meat nor grain is subject to government price controls.

Statement3: Therefore, since per capita income continues to rise, whereas domestic grain production will not increase, price will soon increase for either grain or meat or both.

input_info.O: Premise1: People in gartland who increase their consumption of meat will not radically decrease their consumption of grain.

Argument: Statement1: Newspaper editorial : many pharmaceutical companies develop" me too" drugs, drugs designed to duplicate, more or less, the effect of another company's product that is already on the market. Premise2: If all pharmaceutical companies developed "me too" drugs, fewer innovative drugs would be developed.

Statement4: Therefore, " me too" drugs can indeed damage the development of new drugs.

input_info.Om: Premise2: If all pharmaceutical companies developed "me too" drugs, fewer innovative drugs would be developed.
input_info.O: Premise1: Some "me too" drugs turn out to be more effective than the drugs they were designed to imitate.
input_info.P: Statement1: Newspaper editorial : many pharmaceutical companies develop" me too" drugs, drugs designed to duplicate, more or less, the effect of another company's product that is already on the market. Argument: Statement1: The ergonomic society conducted a study that indicated that many people develop severe back problems during adulthood, and that virtually all such people who received chiropractic treatment showed great improvement. Statement2: Therefore, in order to minimize the proportion of the population that suffers from back pain, the ergonomic society recommended that chiropractic treatment be directed toward those adults who suffer from severe back problems.

Premise2: Any person who receives chiropractic treatment for back pain may also benefit from other forms of treatment.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Any person who receives chiropractic treatment for back pain may also benefit from other forms of treatment.

Argument: Statement1: Because a large disparity in pay between the public and private sectors has developed in recent years, many experienced and extremely capable government administrators have quit their posts and taken positions in private-sector management. Statement2: Government will be able to recapture these capable administrators by raising salaries to a level comparable to those of the private sector. Statement3: In that way, the functioning of public agencies will be improved.
Premise1: People who moved from jobs in government administration to private-sector management would choose to change careers again.
Premise2: If the disparity in pay between government administration and private-sector management increases, administrators will move to the public sector in large numbers.

Statement3: In that way, the functioning of public agencies will be improved.

input_info.Om: Premise2: If the disparity in pay between government administration and private-sector management increases, administrators will move to the public sector in large numbers.
input_info.O: Premise1: People who moved from jobs in government administration to private-sector management would choose to change careers again.

Argument: Statement1: Geologist : a geological fault in the mountain under which the proposed nuclear waste storage facility would be buried could, after a few thousand years, cause the contents to seep out or water to seep in. Statement2: So we should not place a nuclear waste storage facility under this mountain until scientists investigate whether this mountain has any geological faults.
Premise1: The scientists' investigation would conclusively show whether or not the mountain has any geological faults.
Premise2: Nuclear waste could be stored in the proposed facility on a temporary basis.

Statement3: However we could place a nuclear waste storage facility under this mountain before scientists investigate whether this mountain has any geological faults.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Nuclear waste could be stored in the proposed facility on a temporary basis.
input_info.O: Premise1: The scientists' investigation would conclusively show whether or not the mountain has any geological faults.

Argument: Statement1: For over two centuries, no one had been able to make damascus blades-blades with a distinctive serpentine surface pattern-but a contemporary sword maker may just have rediscovered how. Statement2: Using iron with trace impurities that precisely matched those present in the iron used in historic damascus blades, this contemporary sword maker seems to have finally hit on an intricate process by which he can produce a blade indistinguishable from a true damascus blade.
Premise1: Production of damascus blades by sword makers of the past ceased abruptly after those sword makers' original source of iron became exhausted.
Premise2: The iron with which the contemporary sword maker made damascus blades came from a source of iron that was unknown two centuries ago.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: For over two centuries, no one had been able to make damascus blades-blades with a distinctive serpentine surface pattern -because the sword makers died in the war for scrambling the only iron resource of that time. But a contemporary sword maker may just have rediscovered how. Statement2: Using iron with trace impurities, this contemporary sword maker seems to have finally hit on an intricate process by which he can produce a blade indistinguishable from a true damascus blade.

input_info.Om: Premise2: The iron with which the contemporary sword maker made damascus blades came from a source of iron that was unknown two centuries ago.
input_info.O: Premise1: Production of damascus blades by sword makers of the past ceased abruptly after those sword makers' original source of iron became exhausted.

Argument: Statement1: There are two supposedly conflicting hypotheses as to what makes for great national leaders : one is that such leaders successfully shape public opinion, and the other is that they are adept at reacting to it. Premise2: It is impossible to successfully shape public opinion without in some way reacting to it.

Statement3: All leaders who have had successfully shape public opinion have been adroit in reacting to public opinion.

input_info.Om: Premise2: It is impossible to successfully shape public opinion without in some way reacting to it.
input_info.O: Premise1: Having success getting programs passed by the legislature is indicative of being a great national leader.
input_info.P: Statement1: There are two supposedly conflicting hypotheses as to what makes for great national leaders : one is that such leaders successfully shape public opinion, and the other is that they are adept at reacting to it. Argument: Statement1: Researchers hope to find clues about the a'mk peoples who lived in the kaumpta region about one thousand years ago but who left few obvious traces. Statement2: The researchers plan to hire the few remaining shamans of the modern-day indigenous people in kaumpta, who are believed to be descended from the a'mk, to lead them to ancestral sites that may be the remains of a'mk buildings or ceremonial spaces. Statement3: The shamans were taught the location of such sites as part of their traditional training as youths, and their knowledge of traditional kaumpta customs may help determine the nature of any sites the researchers find.
Premise1: The shamans have a reasonably accurate memory of a'mk sites they learned about as youths.
Premise2: Most or all a'mk sites are likely to be found within the kaumpta region.

Please write the modified argument below:

Statement2: The researchers plan to hire the few remaining shamans of the modern-day indigenous people in kaumpta, who are believed to be descended from the a'mk, to lead them to ancestral sites that may be the remains of a'mk buildings or ceremonial spaces. Statement3: The shamans were taught the location of such sites as part of their traditional training as youths, and their knowledge of traditional kaumpta customs may help determine the nature of any sites the researchers find.

input_info.Om: Premise2: Most or all a'mk sites are likely to be found within the kaumpta region.
input_info.O: Premise1: The shamans have a reasonably accurate memory of a'mk sites they learned about as youths.

Argument: Statement1: Many important types of medicine have been developed from substances discovered in plants that grow only in tropical rain forests. Statement2: There are thousands of plant species in these rain forests that have not yet been studied by scientists, and it is very likely that many such plants also contain substances of medicinal value. Statement3: Thus, if the tropical rain forests are not preserved, important types of medicine will never be developed.
Premise1: There are substances of medicinal value contained in tropical rain forest plants not yet studied by scientists that differ from those substances already discovered in tropical rain forest plants.
Premise2: Any substance of medicinal value contained in plant species indigenous to tropical rain forests will eventually be discovered if those species are studied by scientists.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Many important types of medicine have been developed from substances discovered in plants that grow only in tropical rain forests. Statement2: There are thousands of plant species in these rain forests that have not yet been studied by scientists, and it is very likely that many such plants also contain substances of medicinal value. Statement3: Thus, if the tropical rain forests are preserved, substance of medicinal value contained in plant species will be discovered.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Any substance of medicinal value contained in plant species indigenous to tropical rain forests will eventually be discovered if those species are studied by scientists.
input_info.O: Premise1: There are substances of medicinal value contained in tropical rain forest plants not yet studied by scientists that differ from those substances already discovered in tropical rain forest plants.

Argument: Statement1: Over the last five years, every new major alternative-energy initiative that initially was promised government funding has since seen that funding severely curtailed. In no such case has the government come even close to providing the level of funds initially earmarked for these projects. Statement2: Since large corporations have made it a point to discourage alternative-energy projects, it is likely that the corporations'actions influenced the government's funding decisions.
Premise1: The only research projects whose government funding has been severely curtailed are those that large corporations have made it a point to discourage.
Premise2: The funding initially earmarked for a government project is always subject to change, given the mechanisms by which the political process operates.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Over the last five years, every new major alternative-energy initiative that initially was promised government funding has since seen that funding severely curtailed. In no such case has the government come even close to providing the level of funds initially earmarked for these projects. Statement3: Although large corporations have made it a point to discourage alternative-energy projects, corporations'actions might not influence the government's funding decisions.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the reasoning above?
input_info.Om: Premise2: The funding initially earmarked for a government project is always subject to change, given the mechanisms by which the political process operates.
input_info.O: Premise1: The only research projects whose government funding has been severely curtailed are those that large corporations have made it a point to discourage.

Argument: Statement1: Traditional hatcheries raise fish in featureless environments and subject them to dull routines, whereas new, experimental hatcheries raise fish in visually stimulating environments with varied routines. Statement2: Fish raised in the experimental hatcheries, therefore, are more likely to survive after their release.

Premise2: Fish in the wild always live in visually stimulating environments.

Statement3: Fish raised in the experimental hatcheries, therefore, are more similar to the fish in the wild.

Statement3: Fossilized remains of the same species of trees that grew 10,000 years ago have been found 100 meters above the current rocky mountain timberline. Statement4: Clearly, therefore, the climate of the rockymountains during this 10,000 years iscooler than it was 10,000 years ago.

input_info.Om: Premise2: In the past 10, 000 years, the only trees to have grown above today's timberline are the trees whose fossilized remains been found.

Argument: Statement1: On the caribbean island of guadeloupe, a researcher examined 35 patients with atypical parkinson's disease and compared their eating habits to those of 65 healthy adults. Statement2: She found that all of the patients with atypical parkinson's regularly ate the tropical fruits soursop, custard apple, and pomme cannelle, whereas only 10 of the healthy adults regularly ate these fruits. Statement3: From this, she concluded that eating these fruits causes atypical parkinson's.
Premise1: For many of the atypical parkinson's patients, their symptoms stopped getting worse, and in some cases actually abated, when they stopped eating soursop, custard apple, and pomme cannelle.
Premise2: The 10 healthy adults who regularly ate soursop, custard apple, and pomme cannelle ate significantly greater quantities of these fruits, on average, than did the 35 atypical parkinson's patients.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: On the caribbean island of guadeloupe, a researcher examined 35 patients with atypical parkinson's disease and compared their eating habits to those of 65 healthy adults. Statement2: She found that all of the patients with atypical parkinson's regularly ate the tropical fruits soursop, custard apple, and pomme cannelle, but 10 of the healthy adults regularly ate even more. Statement3: From this, she couldn't conclude that eating these fruits causes atypical parkinson's.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the researcher's reasoning?
input_info.Om: Premise2: The 10 healthy adults who regularly ate soursop, custard apple, and pomme cannelle ate significantly greater quantities of these fruits, on average, than did the 35 atypical parkinson's patients.

Argument: Statement1: Chronic fatigue syndrome is characterized by prolonged fatigue, muscular pain, and neurological problems. Statement2: It is not known whether these symptoms are all caused by a single virus or whether each symptom is the result of a separate viral infection. Statement3: A newly synthesized drug has been tested on those who suffer from chronic fatigue syndrome. Although the specific antiviral effects of this drug are unknown, it has lessened the severity of all of the symptoms of chronic fatigue syndrome. Statement4: Thus there is evidence that chronic fatigue syndrome is, in fact, caused by one virus.
Premise1: It is more likely that the new drug counteracts one virus than that it counteracts several viruses.
Premise2: All those who suffer from prolonged fatigue also suffer from neurological problems.

Statement2: It is not known whether these symptoms are all caused by a single virus or whether each symptom is the result of a separate viral infection. Although the specific antiviral effects of this drug are unknown, it has lessened the severity of all of the symptoms of chronic fatigue syndrome. Statement5: Thus there is evidence that chronic fatigue syndrome is, in fact, related to nervous system.

input_info.Om: Premise2: All those who suffer from prolonged fatigue also suffer from neurological problems.
input_info.O: Premise1: It is more likely that the new drug counteracts one virus than that it counteracts several viruses.

Statement4: Thus there is evidence that chronic fatigue syndrome is, in fact, caused by one virus.

Argument: Statement1: Reconstructing ships so that they have a double hull can protect them from serious damage in the roughly 20 percent of shipping accidents that unavoidably result from severe weather conditions. Argument: Statement1: Because ethylene dibromide, a chemical used to fumigate grain, was blamed for the high rate of nerve damage suffered by people who work in grain-processing plants, many such plants switched to other chemical fumigants two years ago. Statement2: Since then, however, the percentage of workers at these plants who were newly diagnosed with nerve damage has not dropped significantly. Statement3: Therefore, either ethylene dibromide was wrongly blamed or else the new chemicals also cause nerve damage.
Premise1: If ethylene dibromide causes nerve damage, it does not take two years or longer for that damage to become detectable.
Premise2: If the new chemicals cause nerve damage, the nerve damage caused would be different from any nerve damage that ethylene dibromide may cause.

Please write the modified argument below:

Statement3: Therefore, either ethylene dibromide was wrongly blamed or else the other chemicals also cause nerve damage.

input_info.Q: Which of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
input_info.Om: Premise2: If the new chemicals cause nerve damage, the nerve damage caused would be different from any nerve damage that ethylene dibromide may cause.
input_info.O: Premise1: If ethylene dibromide causes nerve damage, it does not take two years or longer for that damage to become detectable.

Argument: Statement1: Historian : leibniz, the seventeenth-century philosopher, published his version of calculus before newton did. Statement2: But then newton revealed his private notebooks, which showed he had been using these ideas for at least a decade before leibniz's publication. Statement3: Yet close examination of the letter shows that newton's few cryptic remarks did not reveal anything important about calculus. Statement4: Thus, leibniz and newton each independently discovered calculus.
Premise1: Neither newton nor leibniz learned crucial details about calculus from some third source.
Premise2: No third person independently discovered calculus prior to newton and leibniz.

Statement2: But then newton revealed his private notebooks, which showed he had been using these ideas for at least a decade before leibniz's publication. Newton also claimed that he had disclosed these ideas to leibniz in a letter shortly before leibniz's publication. Statement4: Yet close examination of the letter shows that newton's few cryptic remarks did not reveal anything important about calculus. Statement5: Thus, leibniz and newton first discovered calculus.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the historian's argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: No third person independently discovered calculus prior to newton and leibniz.
input_info.O: Premise1: Neither newton nor leibniz learned crucial details about calculus from some third source.

Statement4: Thus, leibniz and newton each independently discovered calculus.

Argument: Statement1: Early in the twentieth century, lake konfa became very polluted. Statement2: Recently fish populations have recovered as release of industrial pollutants has declined and the lake's waters have become cleaner. Statement3: Fears are now being voiced that the planned construction of an oil pipeline across the lake's bottom might cause harm to the lake and cause the fish population to decline again. Therefore, provided this technology is effective, those fears are groundless. Statement4: However, a technology for neutralizing pollution is being installed.

Argument: Statement1: Jane : television programs and movies that depict violence among teenagers are extremely popular. Statement2: Given how influential these media are, we have good reason to believe that these depictions cause young people to engage in violent behavior. Statement3: Hence, depictions of violence among teenagers should be prohibited from movies and television programs, if only in those programs and movies promoted to young audiences. Statement4: Maurice : but you are recommending nothing short of censorship! Besides which, your claim that television and movie depictions of violence cause violence is mistaken : violence among young people predates movies and television by centuries.
Premise1: The movies that have been shown to have the most influence on young people's behavior are those that are promoted to young audiences.
Premise2: Many adolescents who engage in violent behavior had already displayed such behavior before they were exposed violence in movies.

Please write the modified argument below:

Statement2: Given how influential these media are, we have good reason to believe that these depictions will not cause young people to engage in violent behavior. Statement3: Hence, depictions of violence among teenagers should not be prohibited from movies and television programs, if only in those programs and movies promoted to young audiences. Statement4: Maurice : but you are recommending society without censorship! Besides which, your claim that television and movie depictions of violence can not cause violence is mistaken : violence among grown people postdates movies and television by centuries.

Argument: Statement1: Paleontologist : plesiosauromorphs were gigantic, long-necked marine reptiles that ruled the oceans during the age of the dinosaurs. Premise2: A gigantic marine animal would not be able to find enough food to meet the caloric requirements dictated by its body size if it did not hunt by chasing prey over long distances.

Statement2: Most experts believe that plesiosauromorphs lurked and quickly ambushed their prey. Statement3: However, plesiosauromorphs must hunted by chasing their prey over long distances. Statement4: Because plesiosauromorph fins were quite long and thin, like the wings of birds specialized for long-distance flight.

input_info.Om: Premise2: A gigantic marine animal would not be able to find enough food to meet the caloric requirements dictated by its body size if it did not hunt by chasing prey over long distances.
input_info.O: Premise1: The shape of a marine animal's fin affects the way the animal swims in the same way as the shape of a bird's wing affects the way the bird flies.
input_info.P: Statement1: Paleontologist : plesiosauromorphs were gigantic, long-necked marine reptiles that ruled the oceans during the age of the dinosaurs. Statement2: Most experts believe that plesiosauromorphs lurked and quickly ambushed their prey. Statement3: However, plesiosauromorphs probably hunted by chasing their prey over long distances. Statement4: Plesiosauromorph fins were quite long and thin, like the wings of birds specialized for long-distance flight.

Argument: Statement1: The milk of many mammals contains cannabinoids, substances that are known to stimulate certain receptors in the brain. Statement2: To investigate the function of cannabinoids, researchers injected newborn mice with a chemical that is known to block cannabinoids from reaching their receptors in the brain. Statement3: The injected mice showed far less interest in feeding than normal newborn mice do. Statement4: Therefore, cannabinoids probably function to stimulate the appetite.
Premise1: The chemical that blocks cannabinoids from stimulating their brain receptors does not independently inhibit the appetite.
Premise2: Newborn mice do not normally ingest any substance other than their mothers' milk.

Statement3: The injected mice showed far less interest in feeding their mothers' milk than normal newborn mice do. Statement4: Therefore, cannabinoids probably function to stimulate the appetite.

Argument: Statement1: The conventional process for tanning leather uses large amounts of calcium oxide and sodium sulfide. Statement2: Tanning leather using biological catalysts costs about the same as using these conventional chemicals if the cost of waste disposal is left out of the comparison. However, nearly 20 percent less waste is produced with biological catalysts, and waste disposal is a substantial part of the overall cost of tanning. Statement3: It is therefore less costly to tan leather if biological catalysts are used instead.
Premise1: Disposal of tanning waste produced with biological catalysts does not cost significantly more than disposal of the same amount of waste produced with the conventional process.
Premise2: The biological catalysts that can be used in the tanning process are less costly by weight than are calcium oxide and sodium sulfide.

Please write the modified argument below:

Statement2: Tanning leather using biological catalysts' weight about the same as using these conventional chemicals if the weight of waste disposal is left out of the comparison. However, no less waste is produced with biological catalysts, and waste disposal is a substantial part of the overall cost of tanning. Statement4: It is therefore less costly to tan leather if biological catalysts are used instead.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: The biological catalysts that can be used in the tanning process are less costly by weight than are calcium oxide and sodium sulfide.
input_info.O: Premise1: Disposal of tanning waste produced with biological catalysts does not cost significantly more than disposal of the same amount of waste produced with the conventional process.
